DIV1.P: THE Way of the World A COMEDY.
As it is Acted at the THEATRE in Lincolns-Inn-Fields, BY HIS MAJESTY's Servants.

Q.L: Audire est Operae pretium, procedere recte

DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed for Jacob Tonson; and Sold by James Knapton at the Crown in St. Paul's Church-yard, George Strahan over against the Royal Exchange in Cornhill, and Egbert Sangr at the Post-House near the Temple-Gate in Fleetstreet. 1706.

DIV1.HEAD: To the Right Honourable RALPH Earl of MOUNTAGUE, &c.
DIV1.P: WHether the World will arraign me of Vanity, or not, that I have presum'd to Dedicate this Comedy to Your Lord∣ship, I am yet in Doubt: Tho' it may be it is some de∣gree of Vanity even to doubt of it. One who has at any time had the Honour of Your Lordship's Conversation, cannot be suppos'd to think very meanly of that which he would prefer to your Pe∣rusal: Yet it were to incur the Imputation of too much Sufficien∣cy, to pretend to such a Merit as might abide the Test of Your Lordship's Censure.

Whatever Value may be wanting to this Play while yet it is mine, will be sufficiently made up to it, when it is once become Your Lordship's; and it is my Security, that I cannot have over rated it more by my Dedication, than Your Lordship will dignifie it by Your Patronage.

Those Characters which are meant to be ridicul'd in most of our Comedis, are of Fools so gross, that in my humble Opinion, they should rather disturb than divert the well-natur'd and reflect∣ing Part of an Audience; they are rather Objects of Charity thn Contempt; and instead of moving our Mirth, they ought very often to excite our Compassion.

This Reflection mov'd me to design some Characters, which should appear ridiculous not so much thro' a natural Folly (which is incorrigible, and therefore not proper for the Stage) as thro' an affected Wit; a Wit, which at the same time that it is affected,
is also false. As there is some Difficulty in the Formation of a Character of this Nature, so there is some Hazard which attends the Progress of its Success, upon the Stage: For many come to a Play, so over-charg'd with Criticism, that they very often let fly their Censure, when through their Rashness they have mistaken their Aim. This I had occasion lately to observe: For this Play had been acted two or three Days, before some of these hasty Judges cou'd find the leisure to distinguish betwixt the Character of a Witwoud and a Truewit.

I must bg Your Lordship's Pardon for this Digression from the true Course of this Epistle; but that it may not seem altogether impertinent, I beg, that I may plead the Occasion of it, in part of that Excuse of which I stand in need, for recommending this Comedy to Your Protection. It is only by the Countenance of Your Lordship, and the Few so qualify'd, that such who write with Care and Pains can hope to be distinguish'd: For the Prosti∣tuted Name of Poet promisuously levels all that bear it.

Terence, the most correct Writer in the World, had a Scipio and a Lelius if not to assist him, at least to support him in his Repu∣tation: And notwithstanding his extraordinary Merit, it may be, their Countenance was not more than necssary.

The Purity of his Stile, the Delicacy of his Turns, and the Just∣ness of his Characters, were all of them Beauties, which the grea∣ter Part of his Audience were incapable of Tasting: Some of the coursest Strokes of Plautus, so severely censur'd by Horace, were more likely to affect the Multitude; such, who come with expe∣ctation to laugh out the last Act of a Play, and are better enter∣tain'd with two or three unseasonable Jests, than with the artful Solution of the Fable.

As Terence excell'd in his Performances, so had he great Ad∣vantages to encourage his Undertakings; for he built most on the Foundations of Menander: His Plots were generally modell'd, and his Characters ready drawn to his Hand. He copied Menan∣der; and Menander had no less Light in the Formation of his Characters, rom the Observations of Theophrastus, of whom he was a Disciple; and Theophrastus it is known was not only the Disciple, but the immediate Successor of Aristotle, the first and greatest Judge of Poetry. These were great Models to design by; and the further Advantage which Terence possess'd, towards giving his Plays the due Ornaments of Purity of Stile, and Justness of Manners, was not less considerable, from the Freedom of Con∣versation, which was permitted him with Lelius and Scipio, two
of the greatest and most polite Men of his Age. And indeed, the Privilege of such a Conversation, is the only certain Means of at∣taining to the Perfection of Dialogue.

If it has happen'd in any Part of this Comedy, that I have gain'd a Turn of Stile, or Expression more Correct, or at least more Cor∣rigible than in those which I have formerly written, I must, with equal Pride an Gratitude, ascribe it to the Honour of Your Lordship's admitting me into Your Conversation, and that of a Society where every body else was so well worthy of You, in Your Retirement last Summer from the Town: For it was imme∣diately after, that this Comedy was written. If I have fail'd in my Performance, it is only to be regretted, where there were so many, not inferior either to a Scipio or a Lelius, that there shou'd be one wanting equal to the Capacity of a Terence. If I am not mistaken, Poetry is almost the only Art, which has not yet laid Claim to Your Lordship's Patronage. Architecture, and Painting, to the great Honour of our Country, have flourish'd under Your Influence and Protection. In the mean time, Poetry, the eldest Sister of all Arts, and Parent of most, seems to have re∣sign'd her Birth-right, by having neglected to pay her Duty to Your Lordship; and by permitting others of a later Extraction, to prepossess that Place in Your Esteem, to which none can pre∣tend a better Title. Poetry, in its Nature, is sacred to the Good and Great; the Relation between them is reciprocal, and they are ever propitious to it. It is the Privilege of Poetry to address to them, and it is their Prrogative alone to give it Protection.

This receiv'd Maxim, is a general Apology for all Writers who Consecrate their Labours to great Men: But I could wish at this time, that this Address were exempted from the common Pretence of all Dedications; and that as I can distinguish Your Lordship even among the most Deserving, so this Offering might become remarkable by some particular Instance of Respect, which shou'd assure Your Lordship, that I am, with all due sense of Your ex∣tream Worthiness and Humanity,
DIV1.CLOSER: My LORD, Tour Lordship's most Obedient and most Oblig'd Humble Servant, Will. Congreve,

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE, Spoken by Mrs. Bracegirdle.
DIV1.L: After our Epilogue this Crowd dismisses,
I'm thinking how this Play'll be pull'd to Pieces.
But pray consider, e'er you doom its Fall,
How hard a thing 'twould be, to please you all.
There are some Criticks so with Spleen diseas'd,
They scarcely come inclining to be Pleas'd:
And sure he must have more than mortal Skill,
Who pleases any one against his Will.
Then, all bad Poets we are sure are Foes,
And how their Number's swell'd the Town well knows:
In shoals, I've mark'd 'em judging in the Pit;
Tho' they're on no Pretence for Judgment fit
But that they have been Damn'd for Want of Wit.
Since when, they by their own Offences taught
Set up for Spies on Plays, and finding Fault.
Others there are whose Malice we'd prevent;
Such, who watch Plays, with scurrilous Intent
To mark out who by Characters are meant.
And tho' no perfect Likeness they can trace;
yet each pretends to know the Copy'd Face.
These, with false Glosses feed their own Ill-nature,
And turn to Libel; what was meant a Satire.
May such malicious Fops this Fortune find,
To think themselves alone the Fools design'd:
If any are so arrogantly Vain,
To think they singly can support a Scene,
And furnish Fool enough to entertain.
For well the Learn'd and the Judicious know,
That Satire scorns to stoop so meanly low,
s any one abstracted Fop to show.
For, as when Painters form a matchless Face,
They from each Fair One catch some diff'rent Grace▪
shining Features in one Portrait blend,
To which no single Beauty must pretend:
So Poets oft, do in one Piece expose
elles Assembles of Coques and Beaux.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE, Spoken by Mr. Betterton.
DIV1.L: OF those jew Fools, who with ill Stars are curs'd,
Sure scribbing Fools, call'd Poets, fare the worst.
For they're a sort of Fools which Fortune makes,
And after she as made 'm Fools, for sakes.
With Nature's Oafs 'tis quite a diff'rent Case,
For Fortune favours all her Idiot-Race:
In her own Nest the Cuckow-Eggs we find,
O'er which she broods to hatch the Changling-Kind.
No Portion for her own she has to spare,
So much she doats on her adopted Care.
Poets are Bubbles, by the Town drawn in,
Suffer'd at first some trifling Stakes to win:
But what unequal Hazards do they run!
Each time they write, they venture all they've won:
The 'Squire that's butter'd still, is sure to be undone.
This Author, heretofore, has found your Favour,
But pleads no Merit from his past Behaviour.
To build on that might prove a vain Presumption,
Should Grants to Poets made, admit Resumption:
And in Parnassus he must lose his Seat,
If that be found a forfeited Estate.
He owns, with Toil, be wrought the following Scenes,
But if they're naught ne'er spare him for his Pains:
Damn him the mare; have no Coseration
For Dulness on mature Deliberation.
He swears he'll not resent one hiss'd-off Scene,
Nor, like those peevish Wits, his Play maintain,
Who, to asert their Sense, your Taste arraign.
Some Plot we think he has, and some new Thought;
Some Humour too, no Farce; but that's a Fault.
Satire, he thinks, you aught not to expect,
For so Reform'd a Town, who dares Correct?
To Please, this time, has been his sole Pretence,
He'll not instruct, lst it should give Offence.
Should he by chance a Knave or Fool expose,
That hurts none here, sure here are none of those.
In short, our Play, shall (with your leave to shew it)
Give you one Instance of a Passive Poet.
Who to your Judgments yields all Resignation;
So Save or Damn, after your own Discretion.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT I. SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: A Chocolate-House. Mirabell and Fainall [Rising from Cards.] Betty waiting.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: YOU are a fortunate Man, Mr. Fainall.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Have we done?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira
SP.P: What you please. I'll play on to entertain you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: No, I'll give you your Revenge another time, when you are not so indifferent; you are thinking of something else now, and play too negligently; the Coldness of a losing Gamester lessens the Pleasure of the Winner: I'd no more play with a Man that slighted his ill Fortune, than I'd make Love to a Woman who undervalu'd the Loss of her Reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: You have a Taste extreamly delicate, and are for refi∣ning on your Pleasures.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Prithee, why so reserv'd? Something has put you out of Humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Not at all: I happen to be grave to Day; and you are gay; that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Confss, Millamant and you quarrell'd last Night, after I left you; my fair Cousin has some Humours that wou'd tempt the Patience of a Stoick. What, some Coxcomb came in, and was well receiv'd by her, while you were by.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Witwoud and Petulant; and what was worse, her Aunt, your Wife's Mother, my evil Genius; or to sum up all in her own Name, my old Lady Wishfort came in.—

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: O there it is then—She has a lasting Passion for you, and with Reason.—What, then my Wife was there?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Yes, and Mrs. Marwood and Three or Four more, whom I never saw before; seeing me, they all put on their grave Faces, whisper'd one another; then complain'd aloud of the Vapours, and after fell into a profound Silence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: They had a mind to be rid of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: For which Reason I resolv'd not to stir. At last the good old Lady broke thro' her painful Taciturnity, with an Invective against long Visits. I would not have understood her, but Mil∣lamant joining in the Argument, I rose and with a constrain'd Smile told her, I thought nothing was so easie as to know when a Visit began to be troublesome; she reden'd and I withdrew, without expecting her Reply.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: You were to blame to resent what she spoke only in Com∣pliance with her Aunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: She is more Mistress of her self, than to be under the necessity of such a Resignation.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: What? tho' half her Fortune depends upon her Mar∣rying with my Lady's Approbation?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I was then in such a Humour, that I shou'd have been better pleas'd if she had been less discreet.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
Mira.
SP.P: And who may have been the Foundress of this Sect? My Lady Wishfort, I warrant, who publishes her Detestation of Mankind; and full of the Vigour of Fifty five, declares for a Friend and Ratafia; and let osterity shift for it self, she'll bred no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: The Discovery of your sham Addresses to her, to con∣ceal your Love to her Neice, has provok'd this Separation: Had you dissembl'd better, Things might have continu'd in the State of Nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P:
I did as much as Man cou'd, with any reasonable Con∣science; I proceeded to the very last Act of Flattery with her, and
was guilty of a Song in her Commendation: Nay, I got a Friend to put her into a Lampoon, and complement her with the Impu∣tation of an Affair with a young Fellow, which I carry'd so far, that I told her the malicious Town took notice that she was grown fat of a sudden; and when she lay in of a Dropsie, persuaded her she was reported to be in Labour. The Devil's in't, if an old Wo∣man is to be flatter'd further, unless a Man shou'd endeavour downright personally to debauch her; and that my Virtue forbad me. But for the Discovery of this Amour, I am indebted to your Friend, or your Wife's Friend, Mrs. Marwood.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: What should provoke her to be your Enemy, without she has made you Advances, which you have flighted? Women do not easily forgive Omissions of that Nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: She was always civil to me, till of late; I confess I am not one of those Coxcombs who are apt to interpret a Woman's good Manners to her Prejudice; and think that she who does not refuse 'm ev'ry thing, can refuse 'em nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: You are a gallant Man, Mirabell, and tho' you may have Cruelty enough, not to satisfie a Lady's longing; you have too much Generosity, not to be tender of her Honour. Yet you speak with an Indifference which seems to be affected; and con∣fesses you are conscious of a Negligence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: You pursue the Argument with a Distrust that seems to be unaffected, and confesses you are conscious of a Concern for which the Lady is more indebted to you than your Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Fie, fie Friend, if you grow Censorious I must leave you; —I'll look upon the Gamesters in the next Room.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Who are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Petulant and Witwoud—Bring me some Chocolate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Betty, what says your Clock?

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Turn'd of the last Canonical Hour, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: How pertinently the Jade answers we! Ha? almost one a Clock! [Looking on his Watch.] O, y'are come— Enter a Servant.
Well; is the grand Affair over? You have been something tedious.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir, there's such Coupling at Pancras, that they stand behind one another, as 'twere in a Country Dance. Ours was the last Couple to lead up; and no Hopes appearing of dispatch, besides, the Parson growing hoarse, we were afraid his Lungs would have fail'd before it came to our Turn; so we drove round to Duke's-Place; and there they were rivetted in a Trice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: So, so, you are sure they are Married.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Married and Bedded, Sir: I am Witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Have you the Certificate?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Here it is, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Has the Taylor brought Waitwell's Cloaths home, and the new Liveris?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: That's well. Do you go home again, d'ye hear, and adjourn the Consummation 'till farther Order; bid Waitwell shake his Ears, and Dame Partlet rustle up her Feathers, and meet me at One a Clock by Rosamond's Pond; that I may see her before she returns to her Lady: And as you tender your Ears be secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Joy of your Success, Mirabell; you look pleas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Ay; I have been engag'd in a Matter of some sort of Mirth, which is not yet ripe for Discovery. I am glad this is not a Cabal-Night. I wonder, Fainall, that you who are Mar∣ried, and of Consequence should be discreet, will suffer your Wife to be of such a Party.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Faith, I am not Jealous. Besides, most who are engag'd are Women and Relations; and for the Men, they are of a Kind too Contemptible to give Scandal.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I am of another Opinion. The greater the Coxcomb, always the more the Scandal: For a Woman who is not a Fool, can have but one Reason for associating with a Man that is.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Are you Jealous as often as you see Witwoud entertain'd by Millamant?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Of her Understanding I am, if not of her Person.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: You do her wrong; for to give her her Due, she has Wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: She has Beauty enough to make any Man think so; and Complaisance enough not to contradict him who shall tell her so.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: For a passionate Lover, methinks you are a Man some∣what too discrning in the Failings of your Mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P:
And for a discrning Man, somewhat too passionate a Lover; for I like her with all her Faults; nay, like her for her Faults. Her Follies are so natural, or so artful that they become her; and those Affectations which in another Woman wou'd be o∣dious, serve but to make her more agreeable. I'll tell thee, Fain∣all, she once us'd me with that Insolence, that in Revenge I took her to pieces; sifted her and separated her Failings; I study'd 'em, and got 'em by Rote. The Catalogue was so large, that I was not without Hopes, one Day or other to hate her heartily: To
which end I so us'd my self to think of 'em, that at length, con∣trary to my Design and Expectation, they gave me ev'ry Hour less and less Disturbance; 'till in a few Days it became habitual to me, to remember 'em without being displeas'd. They are now grown as familiar to me as my own Frailties; and in all probabi∣lity in a little time longer I shall like 'em as well.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Marry her, marry her; be half as well acquainted with her Charms, as you are with her Defects, and my Life on't, you are your own Man again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Say you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: I, I, I have Experience: I have a Wife, and so forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: Is one Squire Witwoud here?

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Yes; What's your Business?

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: I have a Letter for him, from his Brother Sir Wilfull, which I am charg'd to deliver into his own Hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: He's in the next Room, Friend—That way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: What, is the chief of that Noble Family in Town, Sir Wilfull Witwoud?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: He is expected to Day. Do you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I have seen him, he promises to be an extraordinary Per∣son; I think you have the Honour to be related to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Yes; he is half Brother to this Witwoud by a former Wife, who was Sister to my Lady Wishfort, my Wife's Mother. If you marry Millamant you must call Cousins too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I had rather be his Relation than his Acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: He comes to Town in order to Equip himself for Travel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: For Travel! Why the Man that I mean is above Forty.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: No matter for that; 'tis for the Honour of England, that all Europe should know we have Blockh of all Ages.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I wonder there is not an Act of Parliament to save the Credit of the Nation, and prohibit the Exportation of Fools.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: By no means, 'tis better as 'tis; 'tis better to Trade with a little Loss, than to be quite caten up, with being overstock'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Pray, are the Follies of this Knight-Errant, and those of the Squire his Brother, any thing related?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Not at all; Witwoud grows by the Knight, like a Med∣lar grafted on a Crab. One will melt in your Mouth, and t'other set your Teeth on edge; one is all Pulp, and the other all Core.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: So one will be Rotten before he be Ripe, and the other will be Rotten without ever being Ripe at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P:
Sir Wilfull is an odd Mixture of Bashfulness and Obstina∣cy.
—But when he's Drunk, he's as loving as the Monster in the Tempest; and much after the same manner. To give the t'other his due; he has something of good Nature, and does not always want Wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Not always; but as often as his Memory fails him, and his common Place of Comparisons. He is a Fool with a good Memory, and some few Scraps of other Folks Wit. He is one whose Conversation can never be approv'd, yet it is now and then to be endur'd. He has indeed one good Quality, he is not Exceptious; for he so passionately affects the Reputation of un∣derstanding Raillery; that he will construe an Affront into a Jest; and call downright Rudeness and ill Language, Satire and Fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: If you have a mind to finish his Picture; you have an Opportunity to do it at full length. Behold the Original.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Afford me your Compassion, my Dears; pity me, Fainall, Mirabell, pity me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I do from my Soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Why, what's the Matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: No Letters for me, Betty?

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Did not the Messenger bring you one but now, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Ay, but no other?

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: No, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: That's hard, that's very hard;—A Messenger, a Mule, a Beast of Burden, h has brought me a Letter from the Fool my Brother, as heavy as a Panegyrick in a Funeral Sermon, or a Co∣py of Commendatory Verses from one Poet to another. And what's worse, 'tis as sure a Forerunner of the Author, as an Epistle Dedicatory.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: A Fool, and your Brother, Witwoud!

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Ay, ay, my half Brother. My half Brother he is, no nearer upon Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Then 'tis possible he may be but half a Fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Good, good Mirabell, le Drole! Good, good, hang him, don't let's talk of him;—Fainall, how does your Lady? Gad, I say any thing in the World to get this Fellow out of my Head. I beg Pardon that I shou'd ask a Man of Pleasure, and the Town, a Question at once so Foreign and Domestick. But I Talk like an old Maid at a Marriage, I don't know what I say: But she's the best Woman in the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: 'Tis well you don't know what you say, or else your Commendation wou'd go near to make me either Vain or Jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: No Man in Town lives well with a Wife but Fainall: Your Judgment Mirabell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: You had better step and ask his Wife; if you wou'd be credibly inform'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Mirabell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Ay.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: My Dear, I ask Ten Thousand Pardons;—Gad I have forgot what I was going to say to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I thank you heartily, heartily.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: No, but prithee excuse me,—my Memory is such a Memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Have a care of such Apologies, Witwoud;—for I never knew a Fool but he affected to complain, either of the Spleen or his Memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: What have you done with Petulant?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: He's reckoning his Mony,—my Mony it was—I have no Luck to Day.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: You may allow him to win of you at Play;—for you are sure to be too hard for him at Repartee: Since you monopo∣lize the Wit that is between you, the Fortune must be his of Course.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I don't find that Petulant confesses the Superiority of Wit to be your Talent, Witwoud.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Come, come, you are malicious now, and wou'd breed Debates.—Petulant's my Friend, and a very honest Fellow, and a very pretty Fellow, and has a smattering—Faith and Troth a pretty deal of an odd sort of a small Wit: Nay, I'll do him Justice. I'm his Friend, I won't wrong him neither.—And if he had but any Judgment in the World,—he wou'd not be altogether contemptible. Come, come, don't detract from the Merits of my Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: You don't take your Friend to be over-nicely bred.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: No, no, hand him, the Rogue has no Manners at all, that I must own—No more Breeding than a Bum-baily, that I grant you,—'Tis pity faith; the Fellow has Fire and Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: What, Courage?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Hum, faith I don't know as to that,—I can't say as to that.—Yes, faith, in a Controversie he'll contradict any Body.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Tho' 'twere a Man whom he fear'd, or a Woman whom he lov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P:
Well, well, he does not always think before he speaks; —We have all our Failings; you are too hard upon him, you are faith. Let me excuse him,—I can defend most of his Faults,
except one or two; one he has, that's the Truth on't, if he were my Brother, I cou'd not acquit him—That indeed I cou'd wish were otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Ay marry, what's that, Witwoud?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: O pardon me—Expose the Infirmities of my Friend. —No, my Dar, excuse me there.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: What I warrant he's unsincere, or 'tis some such Trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: No, no, what if he be? 'Tis no matter for that, his Wit will excuse that: A Wit shou'd no more be sincere, that a Wo∣man constant; one argues a Decay of Parts, as t'other of Beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: May be you think him too positive?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: No, no, his being positive is an Incentive to Argument, and keeps up Conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Too illiterate.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: That! that's his Happiness—His want of Learning, gives him the more Opportunities to shew his natural Parts.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: He wants Words.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Ay; but I like him for that now; for his want of Words gives me the Pleasure very often to explain his Meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: He's Impudent.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: No, that's not it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: What, he speaks unseasonable Truths sometimes, because he has not Wit enough to invent an Evasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Truths! Ha, ha, ha! No, no, since you will have it,— I mean, he never speaks Truth at all,—That's all. He will lie like a Chambermaid, or a Woman of Quality's Porter. Now that is a Fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Coach.
SP.P: Is Master Petulant here, Mistress?

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Coach.
SP.P: Three Gentlewomen in the Coach would speak with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: O brave Petulant, Three!

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: I'll tell him.

SP.SPEAKER: Coach.
SP.P: You must bring Two Dishes of Chocolate and a Glass of Cinnamon-water!

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: That should be for Two fasting Strumpets, and a Bawd troubled with Wind. Now you may know what the Three are.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: You are very free with your Friend's Acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Ay, ay, Friendship without Freedom is as dull as Love without Enjoyment, or Wine without Toasting; but to tell you a Secret, these are Trulls that he allows Coach-hire, and some∣thing more by the Week, to call on him once a Day at publick Places.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: You shall see he won't go to 'em because there's no more Company here to take notice of him.—Why this is nothing to what he us'd to do;—Before he found out this way, I have known him call for himself—

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Call for himself? What dost thou mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Mean, why he wou'd slip you out of this Chocolate-house, just when you had been talking to him—As soon as your Back was turn'd—Whip he was gone;—Then trip to his Lodging, clap on a Hood and Scarf, and Mask, slap into a Hackney-Coach, and drive hither to the Door again in a trice; where he wou'd send in for himself, that I mean, call for himself, wait for himself, nay and what's more, not finding himself, sometimes leave a Letter for himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I confess this is something extraordinary—I believe he waits for himself now, he is so long a coming; O I ask his pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Sir, the Coach stays.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Well, well; I come—Sbud a Man had as good be a pro∣fess'd Midwife as a profess'd Whoremaster, at this rate; to be knock'd up and rais'd at all Hours, and in all Places. Pox on 'em I won't come.—D'ye hear, tell 'em I won't come.— Let 'em snivel and cry their Hearts out.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: You are very cruel, Petulant.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: All's one, let it pass—I have a Humour to be cruel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I hope they are not Persons of Condition that you use at this rate.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Condition, Condition's a dry'd Fig, if I am not in Humour —By this Hand, if they were your—a—a—your What-dee-call-'ems themselves, they must wait or rub off, if I want Appetite.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: What-dee—call-'ems! What are they, Witwoud?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Empresses, my Dear—By your What-dee-call-'ems he means Sultana Queens.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Ay, Roxolana's.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Cry you Mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Witwoud says they are—

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: What does he say th' are?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: I; fine Ladies I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Pass on, Witwoud—Harkee, by this Light his Re∣lations —Two Coheiresses his Cousins, and an old Aunt, that loves Catterwauling better than a Conventile.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha; I had a Mind to see how the Rogue wou'd come off—Ha, ha, ha; Gad I can't be angry with him; if he said they were my Mother and my Sisters.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: No!

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: No; the Rogue's Wit and Readiness of Invention charm me, dear Petulant.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: They are gone, Sir, in great Anger.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Enough, let 'em trundle. Anger helps Complexion, saves Paint.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: This Continence is all dissembled; this is in order to have something to brag of the next time he makes Court to Milla∣mant, and swear he has abandon'd the whole Sex for her Sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Have you not left off your impudent Pretensions there yet? I shall cut your Throat, sometime or other Petulant, about that Business.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Ay, ay, let that pass—There are other Throats to be cut—

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Meaning mine, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Not I—I mean no Body—I know nothing.—But there are Uncles and Nephews in the World—And they may be Rivals—What then? All's one for that—

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: How! Harkee Petulant, come hither—Explain, or I shall call your Interpreter.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Explain, I know nothing—Why you have an Uncle, have you not, lately come to Town, and lodges by my Lady Wishfort's?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: True.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet
SP.P: Why that's enough—You and he are not Friends; and if he shou'd marry and have a Child, you may be disinherited, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Where hast thou stumbled upon all this Truth?

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: All's one for that; why then say I know something.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Come, thou art an honest Fellow Petulant, and shalt make Love to my Mistress, thou sha't, Faith. What hast thou heard of my Uncle?

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: I, nothing I. If Throats are to be cut, let Swords clash; snugs the Word, I shrug and am silent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P:
O Raillery, Raillery. Come, I know thou art in the Women's Secrets—What you're a Cabalist, I know you staid
at Millamant's last Night, after I went. Was there any Mention made of my Uncle, or me? Tell me; if thou hadst but good Na∣ture equal to thy Wit Petulant, Tony Witwoud, who is now thy Competitor in Fame, wou'd shew as dim by thee as a dead Wht∣ting's Eye, by a Pearl of Orient; he wou'd no more be seen by thee, than Mercury is by the Sun: Come, I'm sure thou wo't tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: If I do, will you grant me common Sense then, for the future?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Faith I'll do what I can for thee; and I'll pray that Hea∣ven may grant it thee in the mean time.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Well, harkee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Petulant and you both will find Mirabell as warm a Ri∣val as a Lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Pshaw, pshaw, that she laughs at Petulant is plain. And for my part—But that it is almost a Fashion to admire her, I shou'd—Harkee—To tell you a Secret, but let it go no further—Between Friends, I shall never break my Heart for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: She's handsome; but she's a sort of an uncertain Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: I thought you had dy'd for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Umh—No—

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: She has Wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: 'Tis what she will hardly allow any Body else—Now, Demme, I shou'd hate that, if she were as handsome as Cleopatra. Mirabell is not so sure of her as he thinks for.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Why do you think so?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: We staid pretty late there last Night; and heard something of an Uncle to Mirabell, who is lately come to Town,—and is between him and the best part of his Estate; Mirabell and he are at some Distance, as my Lady Wishort has been told; and you know she hates Mirabell, worse than a Quaker hates a Par∣rot or than a Fishmonger hates a hard Frost. Whether this Uncle has seen Mrs. Millamant or not, I cannot say; but there were Items of such a Treaty being in Embrio; and if it shou'd come to Life, poor Mirabell wou'd be in some sort unfortunately fobb'd ifaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: 'Tis impossible Millamant should harken to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Faith, my Dear, I can't tell; she's a Woman and a kind of a Humorist.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: And this is the Sum of what you cou'd collect last Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: The Quintessence. May be Witwoud knows more, he stay'd longer—Besids they never mind him; they say any thing before him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I thought you had been the greatest Favourite.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Ay teste a teste; But not in publick, because I make Remarks.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Do you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Ay, ay, pox I'm malicious, Man. Now he's soft you know, they are not in awe of him—The Fellow's well bred, he's what you call a—What-d'ye-call-'em. A fine Gentleman, but he's silly withall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I thank you, I know as much as my Curiosity requires. Fainall, are you for the Mall?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Ay, I'll take a Turn before Dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Ay, we'll all walk in the Park, the Ladies talk'd of being there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I thought you were oblig'd to watch for your Brother Sir Wilfulls Arrival.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: No, no, he comes to his Aunt's, my Lady Wishfort; pox on him, I shall be troubled with him too; what shall I do with the Fool?

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Beg him for his Estate; that I may beg you afterwards; and so have but one Trouble with you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: O rare Petulant; thou art as quick as a Fire in a frosty Morning; thou shalt to the Mall with us; and we'll be very severe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Enough, I'm in a Humour to be severe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Are you; Pray then walk by your selves,—Let not us be accessary to your putting the Ladies out of Countenance, with your senseless Ribaldry; which you roar out aloud as often as they pass by you; and when you have made a handsome Wo∣man blush, then you think you have been severe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: What, what? Then let 'em either shew their Innocence by not understanding what they hear, or else shew their Discreti∣on by not hearing what they would not be thought to understand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: But hast not thou then Sense enough to know that thou ought'st to be most asham'd thy self, when thou hast put another out of Countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Not I, by this Hand—I always take Blushing either for a Sign of Guilt, or ill Breeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I confess you ought to think so. You are in the right, that you may plead the Error of your Judgment in defence of your Practice.
SP.L: Where Modesty's ill Manners, 'tis but fit
That Impudence and Malice pass for Wit.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT II. SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: St. James's Park. Enter Mrs. Fainall and Mrs. Marwood.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Ay, ay, dear Marwood, if we will be happy, we must find the Means in our selves, and a∣mong our selves. Men are ever in Extreams, either doting or averse. While they are Lovers, if they have Fire and Sense, their Jealousies are insupportable: And when they cease to Love, (we ought to think at least) they loath; they look upon us with Hor∣ror and Distaste; they meet us like the Ghosts of what we were, and as such fly from us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: True, 'tis an unhappy Circumstance of Life, that Love shou'd ever die before us; and that the Man so often shou'd out-live the Lover. But say what you will, 'tis better to be left, than never to have been lov'd. To pass our Youth in dull In∣difference, to refuse the Sweets of Life because they once must leave us; is as preposterous, as to wish to have been born Old, because we one Day must be Old. For my part, my Youth may wear and waste, but it shall never rust in my Possession.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Then it seems you dissemble an Aversion to Man∣kind, only in compliance with my Mother's Humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Certainly. To be free; I have no Taste of those insipid dry Discourses, with which our Sex of force must enter∣tain themselves, apart from Men. We may affect Endearments to each other, profess eternal Friendships, and seem to dote like Lovers; but 'tis not in our Natures long to persevere. Love will resume his Empire in our Breasts, and every Heart, or soon or late, receive and readmit him as its lawful Tyrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Bless me, how have I been deceiv'd! Why you prosess a Libertine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: You fee my Friendship by my Freedom. Come, be as sincere, acknowledge that your Sentiments agree with mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: You hate Mankind.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Heartily, Inveterately.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Your Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Most transcendently; ay, tho'I say it, meritoriously.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Give me your Hand upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: There.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I join with you; what I have said has been to try you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Is it possible? Dost thou hate those Vipers Men?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I have done hating 'em; and am now come to de∣spise 'em; the next thing I have to do, is eternally to forget 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: There spoke the Spirit of an Amazon, a Penthesilea

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: And yet I am thinking sometimes, to carry my A∣version further.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: You would not make him a Cuckold?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: No; but I'd make him believe I did, and that's as bad.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Why had not you as good do it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: O if he shou'd ever discover it, he wou'd then know the worst; and be out of his Pain; but I wou'd have him ever to continue upon the Rack of Fear and Jealousie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Ingenious Mischief! Wou'd thou were married to Mirabell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Wou'd I were.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: You change Colour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Because I hate him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: So do I; but I can hear him nam'd. But what Rea∣son have you to hate him in particular?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I never lov'd him; he is, and always was insuffe∣rably proud.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: By the Reason you give for your Aversion, one wou'd think it dissembl'd; for you have laid a Fault to his Charge, of which his Enemies must acquit him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: O then it seems you are one of his favourable Ene∣mies. Methinks you look a little pale, and now you flush again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Do I? I think I am a little sick o' the sudden.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: What ails you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: My Husband. Don't you see him? He turn'd short upon me unawares; and has almost overcome me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha; he comes opportunely for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: For you, for he has brought Mirabell with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: My Dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: My Soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: You don't look well to Day, Child.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: D'ye think so?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: He is the only Man that do's, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: The only Man that would tell me so at least? and the only Man from whom I could hear it without Mortification.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: O my Dear I am satisfy'd of your Tenderness; I know you cannot resent any thing from me; especially what is an ef∣fect of my Concern.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Mr. Mirabell, my Mother interrupted you in a plea∣sant Relation last Night: I wou'd fain hear it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: The Persons concern'd in that Affair, have yet a tolera∣ble Reputation—I am afraid Mr. Fainall will be Censorious.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: He has a Humour more prevailing than his Curio∣sity, and will willingly dispence with the hearing of one scanda∣lous Story, to avoid giving an Occasion to make another by be∣ing seen to walk with his Wife. This way Mr. Mirabell, and I dare promise you will oblige us both.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Excellent Creature! Well sure if I shou'd live to be rid of my Wife, I shou'd be a miserable Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Ay!

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: For having only that one Hope, the accomplishment of it, of Consequence must put an End to all my Hopes; and what a Wretch is he who must survive his Hopes! Nothing remains when that Day comes, but to sit down and weep like Alexander, when he wanted other Worlds to conquer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Will you not follow 'm?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Faith, I think not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Pray let us; I have a Reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: You are not Jealous?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Of whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Of Mirabell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: If I am, is it inconsistent with my Love to you that I am tender of your Honour?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: You wou'd intimate then, as if there were a fellow-feeling between my Wife and him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I think she does not hate him to that degree she wou'd be thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: But he, I fear, is too Insensible.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: It may be you are deceiv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: It may be so. I do not now begin to apprehend it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: That I have been deceiv'd Madam, and you are false.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: That I am false! What mean you?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: To let you know I see through all your little Arts— Come, you both love him; and both have equally dissembl'd your Aversion. Your mutual Jealousies of one another, have made you clash 'till you have both struck Fire. I have seen the warm Confession rd'ning on your Cheeks, and sparkling from your Eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: You do me wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: I do not—'Twas for my ase to oversee and wilfully neglect the gross Advances made him by my Wife; that by per∣mitting her to be engag'd, I might continue unsuspected in my Pleasures; and take you oftner to my Arms in full Security. But cou'd you think because the nodding Husband would not wake, that e'er the watchful Lover slept!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: And wherewithall can you reproach me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: With Infidelity, with loving of another, with Love of Mirabell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: 'Tis false. I challenge you to shew an Instance that can confirm your groundless Accusation. I hate him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: And wherefore do you hate him? He is insensible, and your Resentment follows his Neglect. An Instance? The Injuries you have done him are a Proof: Your interposing in his Love. What cause had you to make Discoveries of his pretended Pas∣sion? To undeceive the credlous Aunt, and be the officious Ob∣stacle of his Match with Millamant?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: My Obligations to my Lady urg'd me: I had pro∣fess'd a Friendship to her; and could not see her asic Nature so abus'd by that Dissembler.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: What, was it Conscience then! Profess'd a Friendship! O the pious Friendships of the Female Sex!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: More tender, more sincere, and more enduring, than all the vain and empty Vows of Men, whether professing Love to us, or mutual Faith to one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha; you are my Wife's Friend too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P:
Shame and Ingratitude! Do you reproach me? You, you upbraid me! Have I been false to her, thro' strict Fidelity to you, and sacrific'd my Friendship to keep my Love inviolate? And have you the Baseness to charge me with the Guilt, unmind∣ful of the Merit! To you it shou'd be meritorious, that I have
been vicious. And do you reflect that Guilt upon me, which should lie buried in your Bosom?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: You misinterpret my Reproof. I meant but to remind you of the slight Account you once could make of strictst Ties, when set in Competition with your Love to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: 'Tis false, you urg'd it with deliberate Malice— 'Twas spoke in scorn, and I never will forgive it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Your Guilt, not your Resentment, begets your Rage. If yet you lov'd, you could forgive a Jealousie: But you are stung to find you are discover'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
Fain.
SP.P: Why, what will you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Disclose it to your Wife; own what has past be∣tween us.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Frenzy!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: By all my Wrongs I'll do't—I'll publish to the World the Injuries you have done me, both in my Fame and Fortune: With both I trusted you, you Bankrupt in Honour, as indigent of Wealth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Your Fame I have preserv'd. Your Fortune has been bestow'd as the Prodigality of your Love would have it, in Plea∣sures which we both have shar'd. Yet had not you been false, I had e'er this repaid it—'Tis true—had you permitted Mirabell with Millament to have stoll'n their Marriage, my Lady had been incens'd beyond all Means of Reconcilement: Millamant had for∣feited the Moiety of her Fortune; which then wou'd have de∣scended to my Wife;—And wherefore did I marry, but to make lawful Prize of a rich Widow's Wealth, and squander it on Love and you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Deceit and srivolous Pretence.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Death, am I not Married? What's Pretence? Am I not Imprison'd, Fetter'd? Have I not a Wife? Nay a Wife that was a Widow, a young Widow, a handsome Widow; and would be again a Widow, but that I have a Heart of Proof, and something of a Constitution to bustle thro' the Ways of Wedlock and this World. Will you yet be reconcil'd to Truth and me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Impossible. Truth and you are inconsistent—I hate you, and shall for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: For loving you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I loath the Name of Love after such Usage; and next to the Guilt with which you wou'd asperse me, I scorn you most. Farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Nay, we must not part thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Let me go.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Come, I'm sorry.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I care not—Let me go—Break my Hands, do —I'd leave 'm to get loose.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: I would not hurt you for the World. Have I no other Hold to keep you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Well, I have deserv'd it all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: You know I love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Poor dissembling!—O that—Well, it is not yet—

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: What? What is it not? What is it not yet? It is not yet too late—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: No, it is not yet too late—I have that Com∣fort.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: It is to love another.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: But not to loath, detest, abhor Mankind, my self and the whole treacherous World.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Nay, this is Extravagance—Come I ask your Pardon —No Tears—I was to blame, I cou'd not love you and be asie in my Doubts—Pray forbear—I believe you; I'm convinc'd I have done you wrong; and any way, ev'ry way will make amends;—I'll hate my Wife yet more, Dam her, I'll Part with her, rob her of all she's worth, and will retire somewhere, any where to another World, I'll Marry thee—Be pacify'd— 'Sdeath they come, hide your Face, your Tears—You hve a Mask, wear it a Moment. This way, this way, be persuaded.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: They are here yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: They are turning into the other Walk.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: While I only hated my Husband, I could bear to see him, but since I have despis'd him, he's too offensive.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: You shou'd have just so much Disgust for your Husband, as may be sufficient to make you relish your Lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: You have been the Cause that I have lov'd with∣out Bounds, and wou'd you set Limits to that Aversion, of which you have been the Occasion? Why did you make me marry this Man?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Why do we daily commit disagreeable and dangerous A∣ctions? To save that Idol Reputation. If the Familiarities of our Loves had produc'd that Consequence, of which you were ap∣prehensive, where could you have fix'd a Father's Name with Cre∣dit, but on a Husband? I knew Fainall to be a Man lavish of his Morals, an interested and professing Freind, a false and a design∣ing Lover; yet one whose Wit and outward fair Behaviour, have gain'd a Reputation with the Town, enough to make that Wo∣man stand excus'd, who has suffer'd her sel to be won by his Ad∣dresses. A better Man ought not to have been sacrific'd to the Occasion; a worse had not answer'd to th Purpose. When you are weary of him, you know your Remedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: I ought to stand in some Degree of Credit with you, Mirabell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: In Justice to you, I have made you privy to my whole Design, and put it in your Pow'r to ruin or advance my Fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Whom have you instructed to represent your pre∣tended Uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Waitwell, my Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: He is an humble Servant to Foible my Mother's Wo∣man; and may win her to your Interest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Care is taken for that—She is won and worn by this time. They were married this Morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Who?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Waitwell and Foible. I wou'd not tempt my Servant to betray me by trusting him too far. If your Mother, in hopes to ruin me, shou'd consent to marry my pretended Uncle, he might like Mosca in the Fox, stand upon Terms; so I made him sure before hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: So, if my poor Mother is caught in a Contract, you will discover the Imposture betimes; and release her by pro∣ducing a Certificate of her Gallant's former Marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Yes, upon Condition she consent to my Marriage with her Niece, and surrender the Moiety of her Fortune in her Possession.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: She talk'd last Night of endeavouring at a Match between Millamant and your Uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: That was by Foible's Direction, and my Instruction, that she might seem to carry it more privately.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Well, I have an Opinion of your Succss; for I believe my Lady will do any thing to get a Husband; and when she has this, which you have provided for her, I suppose she will submit to any thing to get rid of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Yes, I think the good Lady would marry any thing that resembl'd a Man, tho' 'twere no more than what a Butler could pinch out of a Napkin.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Female Frailty! We must all come to it, if we live to be Old, and feel the craving of a false Appetite when the true is decay'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: An old Woman's Appetite is deprav'd like that of a Girl—'Tis the Green-Sickness of a second Childhood; and like the faint Offer of a latter Spring, serves but to usher in the Fall; and withers in an affected Bloom.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Here's your Mistress.
SP.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Millamant, Witwoud, and Mincing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Here she comes I faith full Sail, with her Fan spread and her Streamers out, and a Shoal of Fools for Tenders—Ha, no, I cry her Mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: I see but one poor empty Sculler; and he tows her Woman after him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: You seem to be unattended, Madam—You us'd to have the Beau-mond Throng after you; and a Flock of gay fine Perrukes hovering round you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Like Moths about a Candle—I had like to have lost my Comparison for want of Breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: O I have deny'd my self Airs to Day. I have walk'd as fast through the Croud—

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: As a Favourite in Disgrace; and with as few Followers.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Dear Mr. Witwoud, Truce with your Similitudes: For I am as sick of 'em—

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: As a Physician of a good Air—I cannot help it, Ma∣dam, tho' 'tis against my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Yet again! Mincing, stand between me and his Wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Do, Mrs. Mincing, like a Skreen before a great Fire. I confess I do blaze to Day, I am too bright.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: But dear Millamant, why were you so long?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Long! Lord, have I not made violent haste? I have ask'd every living Thing I met for you; I have enquir'd after you, as after a new Fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Madam, Truce with your Similitudes—No, you met her Husband and did not ask him for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: By your leave Witwoud, that were like enquiring after an old Fashion, to ask a Husband for his Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Hum, a hit, a hit, a palpable hit, I confess it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: You were dress'd before I came abroad.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Ay, that's true—O but then I had—Mincing, what had I? Why was I so long?

SP.SPEAKER: Minc.
SP.P: O Mem, your Laship staid to peruse a Pacquet of Letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: O ay, Letters—I had Letters—I am persecuted with Letters—I hate Letters—No Body knows how to write Let∣ters; and yet one has 'em, one does not know why—They serve one to pin up one's Hair.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Is that the way? Pray, Madam, do you pin up your Hair with all your Letters? I find I must keep Copies.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Only with those in Verse, Mr. Witwoud. I never pin up my Hair with Prose. I think I try'd once, Mincing.

SP.SPEAKER: Minc.
SP.P: O Mem, I shall never forget it.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Ay, poor Mincing tift and tit all the Morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Minc.
SP.P: Till I had the Cramp in my Fingers, I'll vow Mem. And all to no purpose. But when your Laship pins it up with Poetry, it sits so pleasant the next Day as any Thing, and is so pure and so crips.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Indeed, so crips?

SP.SPEAKER: Minc.
SP.P: You're such a Critick, Mr. Witwoud.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Mirabell, Did not you take Exceptions last Night? O ay, and went away—Now I think on't I'm angry—No, now I think no't I'm pleas'd—For I believe I gave you some Pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Does that please you?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Infinitely; I love to give Pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: You would affect a Cruelty which is not in your Na∣ture; your true Vanity is in the Power of pleasing.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: O I ask your Pardon for that—Ones Cruelty is ones Power, and when one parts with ones Cruclty, one parts with ones Power; and when one has parted with that, I fancy one's Old and Ugly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Ay, ay, suffer your Cruelty to ruin the Object of your Power, to destroy your Lover—And then how vain, how lost a Thing you'll be! Nay, 'tis true: You are no longer handsome when you've lost your Lover; your Beauty dies upon the Instant: For Beauty is the Lover's Gift; 'tis he bestows your Charms— Your Glass is all a Cheat. The Ugly and the Old, whom the Looking-glass mortifies, yet after Commendation can be flatter'd by it, and discover Beauties in it: For that reflects our Praises, rather than your Face.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P:
O the Vanity of these Men! Fainall▪ d'ye hear him? If they did not commend us, we were n handsome! Now you
must know they could no commend one, if one was not hand∣some. Beauty the Lover's Gift—Lord, what is a Lover, that it can give? Why one makes Lovers as fast as one pleases, and they live as long as one pleases, and they die as soon as one pleases: And then if one pleases one makes more.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Very pretty. Why you make no more of making of Lovers, Madam, than of making so many Card-matches.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
Mira.
SP.P: Yet, to those two vain empty Things, you owe two the greatest Pleasures of your Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: How so?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: To your Lover you owe the Pleasure of hearing your selves prais'd; and to an Eccho the Pleasure of hearing your selves talk.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: But I know a Lady that loves talking so incessantly, she won't give an Eccho fair play; she has that everlasting Rotation of Tongue, that an Eccho must wait 'till she dies, before it can catch her last Words.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: O Fiction; Fainall, let us leave these Men.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Draw off Witwoud.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Immediately; I have a Word or two for Mr. Wit∣woud.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I would beg a little private Audience too—

DIV3.P: You had the Tyranny to deny me last Night; tho' you knew I came to impart a Secret to you that concern'd my Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: You saw I was engag'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Unkind. You had the 'leisure to entertain a Herd of Fools; Things who visit you from their excessive Idleness; be∣stoving on your Easiness that Time, which is the Incumbrance of their Lives. How can you find Delight in such Society? It is impossible they should admire you, they are not capable: Or if they were, it should be to you as a Mortification; for sure to please a Fool is some degree of Folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: I please my self—Besides, sometimes to converse with Fools is for my Health.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Your Health! Is there a worse Disase than the Con∣versation of Fools?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Yes, the Vapours; Fools are Physick for it, next to Assa-faetida.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: You are not in a Course of Fools?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Mirabell, if you prsist in this offensive Freedom—you'll displease me—I think I must resolve after all, not to have you —We shan't agree.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Not in our Physick it may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: And yet our Distemper in all likelihood will be the same; for we shall be sick of one another. I shan't endure to be rpri∣manded, nor instructed, 'tis so dull to act always by Advice, and so tedious to be told of ones Faults—I can't bear it. Well, I won't have you Mirabell—I'm resolv'd—I think—You may go—Ha, ha, ha. What would you give, that you could help loving me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I would give something that you did not know, I cou'd not help it.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Come, don't look grave then. Well, what do you say to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I say that a Man may as soon make a Friend by his Wit, or a Fortune by his Honesty, as win a Woman with Plain-dea∣ling and Sincerity.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Sententious Mirabell! Prithee don't look with that vi∣olent and inflexible wife Face, like Solomon at the dividing of the Child in an old Tapestry Hanging.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: You are merry, Madam, but I would persuade you for one Moment to be serious.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: What, with that Face? No, if you keep your Coun∣tenance, 'tis impossible I shou'd hold mine. Well, after all, there is something very moving in a love-sick Face. Ha, ha, ha— Well I won't laugh, don't be peevish—Heigho! Now I'll be melancholy, as melancholy as a Watch-light. Well Mirabell, if ever you will win me woo me now—Nay, if you are so tedi∣ous, fare you well;—I see they are walking away.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Can you not find in the variety of your Disposition one Moment—

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: To hear you tell me Foible's marry'd, and your Plot like to speed—No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: But how you came to know it—

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Unless by the help of the Devil, you can't imagine; un∣less she should tell me her self. Which of the two it may have been, I will leave you to consider; and when you have done thinking of that, think of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P:
I have something more—Gone—Think of you! To think of a Whirlwind, tho' 'twere in a Whirlwind, were a
Case of more steady Contemplation; a very Tranquility of Mind and Mansion. A Fellow that lives in a Windmill, has not a more whimsical Dwelling than the Heart of a Man that is lodg'd in a Woman. There is o Point of the Compass to which they can∣not turn, and by which they are not turn'd; and by one as well as another; for Motion not Method is their Occupation. To know this, and yet continue to be in Love, is to be mae wise from the Dictates of Reason, and yet persevere to play the Fool by the force of Instinct.—O here come my Pair of Turtles,— What, billing so sweetly! Is not Valentine's Day over with you yet?

DIV3.P: Sirrah, Waitwell, why sure you think you were marry'd for your own Recreation, and not for my Conveniency.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Your Pardon, Sir. With Submission, we have indeed been solacing in lawful Delights; but still with an Eye to Business, Sir. I have instructed her as well as I could. If she can take your Directions as readily as my Instructions, Sir, your Affairs are in a prosperous way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Give you Joy, Mrs. Foible.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: O-las, Sir, I'm so asham'd—I'm afraid my Lady has been in a Thousand Inquietudes for me. But I protest, Sir, I made as much haste as I could.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: That she did indeed, Sir. It was my Fault that she did not make more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: That I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: But I told my Lady as you instructed me, Sir. That I had a prospect of seeing Sir Rowland your Uncle; and that I wou'd put her Ladiship's Picture in my Pocket to shew him; which I'll be sure to say has made him so enamour'd of her Beauty, that he burns with Impatience to ye at her Ladiship's Feet and wor∣ship the Original.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Excellent Foible! Matrimony has made you eloquent in Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: I think she has profited, Sir. I think so.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: You have seen Madam Millamant, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: I told her, Sir, because I did not know that you might find an Opportunity; she had so much Company last Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Your Diligence will merit more—In the mean time—

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: O dear Sir, your humble Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Spouse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Stand off Sir, not a Penny—Go on and prosper, Foi∣ble —The Leas shall be made good and the Farm stock'd, if we succeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: I don't question your Generosity, Sir: And you need not doubt of Success. If you have no more Commands, Sir, I'll be gone; I'm sure my Lady is at her Toilet, and can't dress 'till I come.—O dear, I'm sure that [Looking out.] was Mrs. Mar∣wood that went by in a Mask; if the has seen me with you I'm sure she'll tell my Lady. I'll make haste home and prevent her. Your Servant Sir. B'w'y Waitwell.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Sir Rowland if you please. The Jade's so pert upon her Preferment she forgets her self.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Come Sir, will you endeavour to forget your self— and transform into Sir Rowland.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Why Sir; it will be impossible I shou'd remember my self—Marry'd, Knighted and attended all in one Day! 'Tis enough to make any Man forget himself. The Difficulty will be how to recover my Acquaintance and Familiarity with my former self; and fall from my Transformation to a Reformation into Waitwell. Nay, I shan't be quite the same Waitwell neither—for now I remember me, I'm marry'd, and can't be my own Man again.

DIV3.L: Ay there's my Grief; that's the sad Change of Life;
To lose my Title, and yet keep my Wife.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT III. SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: A Room in Lady Wishfort's House.
Lady Wishfort at her Toilet, Peg waiting.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: MErciful, no News of Foible yet? Peg. No, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I have no more Patience—If I have not fretted my self 'till I am pale again, there's no Veracity in me. Fetch me the Red—the Red, do you hear, Sweet-heart? An errant Ash co∣lour, as i'm a person. Look you how this Wench stirs! Why dost thou not fetch me a little Red? Didst thou not hear me, Mopus?

SP.SPEAKER: Peg.
SP.P: The red Ratafia does your Ladiship mean, or the Cher∣ry-Brandy?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Ratafia, Fool. No, Fool. Not the Ratafia, Fool— Grant me Patience! I mean the Spanish Paper, Idiot, Complexi∣on Darling. Paint, Paint, Paint, dost thou understand that, Changeling, dangling thy Hands like Bobbins before thee. Why dost thou not stir, Puppet? thou wooden Thing upon Wires.

SP.SPEAKER: Peg.
SP.P: Lord, Madam, your Ladiship is so impatient—I can∣not come at the Paint, Madam; Mrs. Foible has lock'd it up, and carry'd the Key with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: A Pox take you both—Fetch me the Cherry-Brandy then—[Exit Peg.]—I'm as pale and as faint, I look like Mrs. Qualmsick the Curate's Wife, that's always breeding— Wench, come, come, Wench, what are thou doing, Sipping? Tasting? Save thee, dost thou not know the Bottle?
SP.STAGE: Enter Peg with a Bottle and China Cup.

SP.SPEAKER: Peg.
SP.P: Madam, I was looking for a Cup.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: A Cup, save thee, and what a Cup hast thou brought! Dost thou take me for a Fairy, to drink out of an Acorn? Why didst thou not bring thy Thimble? Hast thou ne'er a Brass-Thim∣ble clinking in thy Pocket with a bit of Nutmeg? I warrant thee. Come, fill, fill.—So—again. See who that is—[One knocks.] Set down the Bottle first. Here, here, under the Table—What would'st thou go with the Bottle in thy Hand like a Tapster. As I'm a Person, this Wench has liv'd in an Inn upon the Road, before she came to me, like Maritorne's the Asturian in 'Do Quixote. No Foible yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Peg.
SP.P: No Madam, Mrs. Marwood.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O Marwood, let her come in. Come in good Marwood.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I'm surpriz'd to find your Ladiship in dishabille at this time of day.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Foible's a lost Thing; has been abroad since Morning, and never heard of since.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I saw her but now, as I came mask'd through the Park, in Conference with Mirabell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: With Mirabell! You call my Blood into my Face, with mentioning that Traitor. She durst not have the Confidence. I sent her to negotiate an Affair, in which if I'm detected I'm un∣done. If that wheadling Villain has wrought upon Foible to de∣tect me, I'm ruin'd. Oh my dear Freind, I'm a Wretch of Wretch∣es if I'm defected.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: O Madam, you cannot suspect Mrs. Foible's Integrity.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O, he carries Poison in his Tongue that would corrupt Integrity it self. If she has given him an Opportunity, she has as good as put her Integrity into his Hands. Ah dear Marwood, what's Integrity to an Opportunity?—Hark! I hear er— Go you Thing and send her in.—[Exit Peg.]—Dear Friend re∣tire into my Closet, that I may examine her with more Freedom— You'll pardon me dear Friend, I can make bold with you—There are Books over the Chimney—Quarles and 'Pryn, and the Short View of the Stage, with Bunyan's Works to entertain you.

DIV3.P: O Foible, where hast thou been? what hast thou been doing?

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Madam, I have seen the Party.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: But what hast thou done?

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Nay, 'tis your Ladiship has done, and are to do; I have only promis'd. But a Man so enamour'd—so transported! Well, if worshipping of Pictures be a Sin—Poor Sir Rowland. I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: The Miniature has been counted like.—But hast thou not betray'd me, Foible? Hast thou not detected me to that faithless Mirabell?—What hadst thou to do with him in the Park? Answer me, has he got nothing out of thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: So, the Devil has been before-hand with me, what shall I say?—Alas, Madam, cou'd I help it, if I met that confi∣dent Thing? Was I in Fault? If you had heard how he us'd me, and all upon your Ladiship's Account, I'm sure you wou'd not suspect my Fidelity. Nay, if that had been the worst I could have born: But he had a Fling at your Ladiship too; and then I could not hold: But i'faith I gave him his own.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Me? What did the filthy Fellow say?

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: O Madam; 'tis a Shame to say what he said—With his Taunts and his Fleers, tossing up his Nose. Humh (says he) what you are a hatching some Plot (says he) you are so early a∣broad, or Catering (says he) ferreting for some disbanded Offi∣cer I warrant—Half Pay is but thin Subsistance (says he)— Well, what Pension does your Lady propose? let me see (says he) waht she must come down pretty deep now, she's superannu∣ated (says he) and—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Ods my Life, I'll have him, I'll have him murder'd. I'll have him poison'd. Where does he eat? I'll marry a Drawer to have him poison'd in his Wine. I'll send for Robin from Lockets —Immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Poison him? Poisoning's too good for him. Starve him, Madam, strave him; marry Sir Rowland, and get him disinheri∣ted. O you would bless your self, to hear what he said.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: A Villain, superannuated!

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Humh (says he) I hear you are laying Designs against me too (says he) and Mrs. Millamant is to marry my Uncle; (he does not suspect a Word of your Ladiship;) but (says he) I'll fit you for that, I warrant you (says he) I'll hamper you for that (says he) you and your old Frippery too (says he) I'll handle you—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Audacious Villain! handle me, wou'd he durst—Frip∣pery? old Frippery! Was there ever such a foul-mouth'd Fellow? I'll be marry'd to Morrow, I'll be contracted to Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: The sooner the better, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Will Sir Rowland be here, say'st thou? when, Foible?

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Incontinently, Madam. No new Sherisf's Wife expects the Return of her Husband after Knighthood, with that Impati∣ence in which Sir Rowland burns for the dear Hour of kissing your Ladiship's Hand after Dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Frippry! Superannuated Frippery! I'll Frippery the Villain; I'll reduce him to Frippery and Rags: A Tatterdemalli∣on— I hope to see him hung with Tatters, like a Long-Lane Pent-house, or a Gibbe-Thief. A slander-mouth'd Railer: I warrant the Spendthrift Prodigal's in Debt as much as the Milli∣on Lottery, or the whole Court upon a Birth-Day. I'll spoil his Credit with his Tailor. Yes, he shall have my Niece with her Fortune, he shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: He! I hope to see him lodge in Ludgate first, and angle into Black Friars for Brass Farthings, with an old Mitten.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Ay dear Foible; thank thee or that, dear Foible. He has put me out of all Patience. I shall never recompose my Fea∣tures, to receive Sir Rowland with any Oeconomy of Face. This Wretch has fretted me that I am absolutely decay'd. Look Foible.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Your Ladiship has sown'd a little too rashly, indeed Ma∣dam. There are some racks discernable in the white Vernish.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Let me see the Glass—racks, say'st thou? Why I am arrantly lea'd—I look like an old peel'd Wall. Thou must repair me, Foible, before Sir Rowland comes; or I shall never keep up to my Picture.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: I warrant you, Madam; a little Art once made your Pi∣cture like you; and now a little of the same Art must make you like your Picture. Your Picture must sit for you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: But art thou sure Sir Rowland will not ail to come? Or will a not fail when he does come? Will he be Importunate, Foible, and push? For if he should not be Importunate—I shall never break Dcorums—I shall die with Confusion, if I am sore'd to advance—Oh no, I can never advance—I shall swoon if he should expect Advances. No, I hope Sir Rowland is better bred, than to put a Lady to the necessity of breaking her Forms. I won't be too coy neither.—I won't give him Despair— But a little Disdain is not amiss; a little Scorn is alluring.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: A little Scorn becomes your Ladiship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Yes, but Tenderness becomes me best—A sort of a Dyingness—You see that Picture has a sort of a—Ha Foible? A Swimmingness in the Eyes—Yes, I'll look so—My Niece affects it; but she wants Features. Is Sir Rowland handsome? Let my Toilet be remov'd—I'll dress above. I'll receive Sir Rowland here. Is he handsome? Don't answer me. I won't know: I'll be surpriz'd. I'll be taken by Surprize.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: By Storm, Madam. Sir Rowland's a brisk Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Is he! O then he'll Importun, if he's a brisk Man. I shall save Decorums if Sir Rowland importunes. I have a mortal Terror at the Apprechension of offending against Decorums. O I'm glad he's a brisk Man. Let my Things be remov'd, good Foible.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: O Foible, I have been in a Fright, lest I should come too late. That Devil, Marwood, saw you in the Park with Mi∣rabell, and I'm afraid will discover it to my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Discover what, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Nay, nay, put not on that strange Face. I am privy to the whol Design, and know that Waitwell, to whom thou wert this Morning mrry'd, is to personate Mirabell's Uncle, and as such winning my Lady, to involve her in those Difficulties from which Mirabell only must release her, by his making his Conditions to have my Cousin and her Fortune lest to her own Disposal.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: O dear Madam, I beg your Pardon. It was not my Confidence in your Ladiship that was desicient; but I thought the former good Corespondence between your Ladiship and Mr. Mirabell, might have hinder'd his communicating this Secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Dear Foible, forget that.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P:
O dear Madam, Mr. Mirabell is such a sweet winning Gentleman—But your Ladiship is the Pattern of Generosity.—
Sweet Lady. to be so good! Mr. Mirabell cannot chuse but be grateful. I find your Ladiship has his Heart still. Now, Madam, I can safely tell your Ladship our Success. Mrs. Marwood had told my Lady; but I warrant I manag'd my self. I turn'd it all for the better. I told my Lady that Mr. Mirabell rail'd at her. I laid horrid Things to his Charge, I'll vow; and my Lady is so incens'd, that she'll be contracted to Sir Rowland to Night, she says;—I warrant I work'd her up, that he may have her for asking for, as they say of a elsh Maiden head.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: O are Foible!

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Madam, I beg your Ladiship to acquaint Mr. Mirabell of his Success. I would be seen as little as possible to speak to him,—besides. I believe Madam Marwood watches me.— She has a Month's Mind; but I know Mr. Mirabell can't abide her.—[Enter Footman.] John—remove my Lady's Toilet. Madam, your Servant. My Lady is so impatient, I fear she'll come for me, if I stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: I'll go with you up the back Stairs, lest I should meet her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Indeed, Mrs. Engine, is it thus with you? Are you become a go-between of this Importance? Yes, I shall watch you. Why this Wench is the Pass-par-tout, a very Master-Key to every Body's strong Box. My Friend Fainall, have you carry'd it so swimmingly? I thought there was something in it; but it seems it's over with you. Your Loathing is not from a want of Appetie then, but from a Surfit. Else you could never be so cool to fall from a Principal to be an Asislant; to procure for him! A Pat∣tern of Generosity, that I confss. Well, Mr. Fainall, you have met with your match.—O Man, Man! Woman, Woman! The Devil's an Ass: If I were a Painter, I would draw him like an Idot, a Driveler, with a Bib and Bells. Man should have his Head and Horns, and Woman the rest of him. Poor simple Fiend! Madam Mawood has a Month's Mind, but he can't abide her—'Twere better for him you had not been his Confessor in that Affair; without you could have kept his Counsel closer. I shall not prove another Pattern of Generosity, and stalk for him, 'till he takes his Stand to aim at a Fortune, he has not oblig'd me to that, with those Excesses of himself; and now I'll have none of him. Here comes the good Lady, panting ripe; with a Heart full of Hope, and a Head full of Care, like any Chymst upon the Day of Projection.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O dear Marwood what shall I say, for this rude Forget∣fulness— But my dear Friend is all Goodness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: No Apologies, dear Madam. I have been very well entertain'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: As I'm a Person I am in a very Chaos to think I shou'd so forget my self—But I have such an Olio of Asairs really I know not what to do—[Calls]—Foible—I expect my Ne∣phew Sir Willfullev'ry Moment too:—Why Foible—He means to Travel for Improvement.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Methinks Sir Willfull should rather think of marry∣ing than Travelling at his Years. I hear he is turn'd of Forty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O he's in less Danger of being spoil'd by his Travels— I am against my Nephew's marrying too Young. It will be time enough when he comes back, adn has acquir'd Discretion to chuse for himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Methinks Mrs. Millamant and he wou'd make a ve∣ry fit Match. He may Travel afterwards. 'Tis a Thing very usual with young Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I promise you I have thought on't—And since 'tis your Judgment, I'll think on't again. I assure you I will; I va∣lue your Judgment extreamly. On my Word I'll propose it.

DIV3.P: Come, come Foible—I had forgot my Nephew will be here be∣fore Dinner—I must make haste.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
