SP.P: Mr. Witwoud and Mr. Petulant, are come to Dine with our Ladiship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O Dear, I can't appear till I am dress'd. Dear Mar∣wood shall I be free with you again, and beg you to entertain 'cm. I'll make all imaginable haste. Dear Frend excuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Sure never any thing was so Unbred as that odious Man. —Marwood, your Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: You have a Colour, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: That horrid Fellow Petulant, has provok'd me into a Flame—I have broke my Fan—Mincing, lend me yours,— Is not all the Powder out of my Hair?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: No. What has he done?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Nay, he has done nothing; he has only talk'd—Nay, he has said nothing neither; but he has contradicted ev'ry Thing that has been said. For my part, I thought Withwoud and he wou'd have quarrell'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Minc.
SP.P: I vow Mem, I thought once they wou'd have fit.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Well, 'tis a lamentable thing I swear, that one has not the Liberty of chusing one's Acquaintance as one does ones Cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: If we had the Liberty, we shou'd be as weary of one Set of Acquanintance, tho' never so good, as we are of one Suit, tho' never so fine A Fool and a 'Daily Stuff wou'd now and then d Days of Grace, and be worn for Variety

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: I could consent to wear 'cm, if they wou'd wear alike; but Fools never wear out—They are such Drap-du-berry Things! Without one cou'd give 'cm to ones Chamber-maid af∣ter a Day or two.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: 'Twere better so indeed. Or what think you of the Play-house? A fine gay glosly Fool shou'd be given there, like a new masking Habit, after the Masqucrade is over, and we have done with the Disguise. For a Fool's Visit is always a Dis∣guise; and never admitted by a Woman of Wit, but to blind her Affair with a Lover of Sense. If you wou'd but appear bare∣fac'd now, and own Mirabell; you might as easily put off Petu∣lant and Witwoud, as your Hood and Scarf. And indeed 'tis time, for the Town has found it: The Secret is grown too big for the Pretence: 'Tis like Mrs. 'Prin great Belly; she may lace it down before, but it burnih's on her Hips. Indeed, Mil∣lamant, you can no more conceal it, than my Lady Strammel can her Face, that goodly Face, which in Defiance of her Rhenish∣wine Tea, will not be comprehonded in a Mask.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: I'll take my Death, Marwood, you are more Censorious than a decay'd Beauty, or a disearded Toast, Mincing, tell the Men they may come up. My Aunt is not dressing; their Folly is less provoking than your Malice. The Town has found it. [Exit Mincing.] What has it found? That Mirabell loves me is no more a Secret, than it is a Secret that you discover'd it to my Aunt, or than the Reason whyyou discover'd it is a Secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: You are nettl'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mill.
SP.P: You're mistaken. Ridiculous!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Indeed, my Dear, you'll tear another Fan, if you don't mitigate those violent Airs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mill.
SP.P:
O silly! Ha, ha, ha. I cou'd laugh immoderately. Poor Mirabell! His Constancy to me has quite destroy'd his Complai∣sance for all the World beside. I swear, I never enjoin'd it him, to be so coy—If I had the Vanity to think he wou'd obey
me; I wou'd command him to hew mor. Gallantry—'Tis hardly well bred to be so particular on one Hand, and so insensi∣ble one the other. But I despair to prevail, and so let him fol∣low his own Way. Ha, ha, ha. Pardon me, dear Creature, I must laugh, ha, ha, ha; tho' I grant you 'tis a little barbarous, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: What pity 'tis, so much fine Railery, and deliver'd with so significant Gesture, shou'd be so unhappily directed to miscarry.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: H? Dear Creature I ask your Pardon—I swear I did not mind you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Mr. Mirabell and you both may think it a Thing impossible, when I shall tell him by telling you—

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: O dear, what? for it is the same thing, if a hear it— Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: That I detest him, hate him, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: O Madam, why so do I—And yet the Creature loves me, ha, ha, ha. How can one forbear laughing to think of it— I am a Sybil if I am not amaz'd to think what he can see in me. I'll take my Death, I think you are handsomer—and within a Year or two as young.—If you cou'd but stay for me, I shou'd overtake you—But that cannot be—Well, that Thought makes me melanholy—Now I'll be sad.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Your merry Note may be chang'd sooner than you think.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: D'ye say so? Then I'm resolv'd I'll have a Song to keep up my Spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Minc.
SP.P: The Gentlemen stay but to Comb, Madam; and will wait on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Desire Mrs.—that is in the next Room to sing the Song I wou'd have learnt Yesterday. You shall hear it, Madam —Not that there's any great matter in it—But 'tis agreeable to my Humour.

DIV1.HEAD: SONG
DIV1.BYLINE: Set by Mr. John Eccles, and Song by Mrs. Hodgson.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: LOVE's but the Frailty of the Mind,
A sickly Flame, which if not fed expires;
And feeding, wasles in Self-consuming Fires.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: 'Tis not to wound a wanton Boy
Or am'rous Touth, that gives the Joy;
But 'tis the Glory to have pierc'd a Swain,
For whom inferior Beauties sigh'd in vain.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: Then I alone the Conquest prize,
When I insult a Rival's Eres:
If there's Delight in Love, 'tis when I see
That Heart which others bleed for, bleed for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Is your Animosity compos'd, Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Raillery, Raillery, Madam, we have no Animosity— We hit off a little Wit now and then, but no Animosity— The falling out of Wits is like the falling out of Lovers—We agree in the main, like Treble and B se. Ha, Petulant!

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Ay in the main—But when I have a Humour to con∣tradict.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Ay, when he has a Humour to contradict, then I contra∣dict too. What, I know my Cue. Then we contradict one ano∣ther like two Battle-dores: For Contradictions beget one another like Fews.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: If he says Black's Black—If I have a Humour to say 'tis Blue—Let that pass—All's one for that. If I have a Hu∣mour to prove it, it must be granted.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Not positively must—But it may—It may.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Yes, it positively must, upon Proof posive.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Ay, upon Proof positive it must; but upon Proof pre∣sumptive it only may. That's a Logical Distinction now, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I perceive your Debates are of Importance, and ve∣ry learnedly handl'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Importance is one Thing, and Learning's another; but a Debate's a Debate, that I assert.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Petulants' an Enemy to Learning; he relics altogether on his parts.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: No, I'm no Enemy to Learning; it hurts not me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: That's a Sign indeed its no Enemy to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: No, no, it's no Enemy to any Body, but them that have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Well, an illiterate Man's my Aversion. I wonder at the Impadence of any illiterate Man, to offer to make Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: That I confess I wonder at too.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Ah! to marry an Ignorant! that can hardly Read or Write. Pet. Why should a Man be ever the further from being Marry'd tho' he can't read, any more than he is from being Hang'd. The Ordinary's paid for setting the Psalm, and the Parish-priest for reading the Ceremony. And for the rest which is to follow in both Cases, a Man may do it without Book—So all's one for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: D'ye hear the Creature? Lord, here's Company. I'll be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: In the Name of Bartlemew and his Fair, what have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: 'Tis your Brother, I fancy. Don't you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Not I—Yes, I think it is he—I've almost sorgot him; I have not seen him since the Revolution.
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir Willfull Witwoud in a Country Riding Habit, and Servant to Lady Wishsort.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir, my Lady's dressing. Here's Company; if you please to walk in, in the mean time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Dressing! What it's but Morning here I warrant with you in London; we should count it towards Afternoon in our Parts, down in Shropshire—Why then belike my Aunt han;t din'd yet—Ha, Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Your Aunt, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: My Aunt, Sir yes my Aunt, Sir, and your Lady, Sir; your Lady is my Aunt, Sir—Why, what do'st thou not know me, Friend? Why then send some Body here that does. How long hast thou liv'd with thy Lady, Fellow ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: A Week, Sir, longer than any Body in the House, ex∣cept my Lady's Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Why then belike thou dost not know thy Lady, if thou seest her, ha Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Why truly Sir, I cannot sfely swear to her Face in a Morning, before she is dress'd.'Tis like I may give a shrewd guess at her by this time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, prithee try what thou canst do; if thou canst not guess, enqurie her out, do'st hear, Fellow? And tell her, her Nephew, Sir Willfull Witwoud, is in the House.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: I shall, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Hold ye, hear me, Friend; a Word with you in your Ear, prithee who are these Gallants?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Really, Sir, I can't tell; here come so many here, 'tis hard to know 'em all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Oons this Fellow knows less than a Starling; I don't think a knows his own Name.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Mr. Witwoud, your Brother is not behind Hand in Forgetfulness—I fancy he has forgot you too.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: I hope so—The Devil take him that remembers first, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Save you Gentlemen and Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: For shame, Mr. Witwoud; why won't you speak to him?—And you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Petulant speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: And you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: No Offence, I hope

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: No sure, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: This is a vile Dog, I see that already. No Offence! Ha, ha, ha, to him; to him Petulant, smoke him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: It seems as if you had come a Journey, Sir, hem, hem.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Very likely, Sir, that it may seem so.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: No Oence, I hope, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Smoke the Boots, the Boots; Petulant, the Boots; Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: May be not, Sir; thereafter as 'tis meant, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Sir, I presume upon the Information of your Boots.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Why, 'tis like you may, Sir: If you are not satisfy'd with the Information of my Boots, Sir, if you will step to the Stable, you may enquire further of my Horse, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Your Horse, Sir! Your Horse is an Ass, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Do you speak by way of Offence, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: The Gentleman's merry, that's all. Sir—S'life, we shall have a Quarrel betwixt an Horse and an Ass, before they find one another out. You must not take any thing amiss from your Friends, Sir. You are amon; your Friends here, tho' it may be you don't know it—If I am not mistaken, you are Sir Wiliful Witwoud.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Right, Lady; I am Sir Willfull Witwoud, so I write my self; no Offence to any Body, I hope; and Nephew to the Lady Wishfort, of this Mansion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Don't you know this Gentleman, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
Hum! What, sure 'tis not—Yea by'r Lady, but 'tis—'Sheart I know not whether 'tis or no—Yea but 'tis,
by the Rekin. Brother Anthony! What Tony, I aith! What do'st thou not know me? By'r Lady nor I thee, thou art so Bravated, and so Bperriwig'd—'Sheart why do'st not speak? Art thou o'er joy'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Odso Brother, is it you? Your Servant. Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Your Servant! Why yours, Sir. Your Servant again— 'Sheart, and your Friend and Servant to that—And a— (puff) and a Flap Dragon for your Service, Sir And a Hare's Foot, and a Hare's Sut for your Service, Sir; an you be so cold and so courtly!

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: No Offence, I hope, Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: 'Sheart, Sir, but there is, and much Oence— A Pox, is this your Inns o'Court Breeding not to know your Friends and your Relations, your Elders, and your Bttrs?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Why, Brother Willfull of Salop, you may be as tho as a Shrewsbury Cake, if you please. But I tell you, 'tis not modish to know Relations in Town. You think you're in the Country where great lubberly Brothers flabber and kiss one another when they meet, like a Call of Srjeants—'I is not the Fashion here; 'tis not indeed, dear Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: The Fashion's a Fool; and you're a Fop, dear Bro∣ther. 'Sheart, I've suspected this—By'r Lady I conjectur'd you were a Fop, since you began to change the Stile of your Let∣ters, and write in a srap of Paper gil round the Edges, no broader than a . I might expect this, when you left off Honour'd Brother; and hoping you are in good Health, and so forth—To begin with a Rat me, Knight, I'm so sick of a last Nigts Debauch—O ds eart, and then tll a familiar Tale of a Cock and a Bull and a Whore and a Bottle, and so conclude— You could write News before you were out of your Tim, when you liv'd with honest Pumple-Nose the Attorney of Furnival's Inn—You cou'd intreat to be remember'd then to your Friends round the Rekin. We could have Gazetts then, and Dawk's Letter, and the Weekly-Bill, 'till of late Days.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Slife, Witwoud, were you ever an Attorney's Clerk? Of the Family of the Furnivals. Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Ay, ay, but that was for a while. Not long, not long; pshaw, I was not in my own Power then. An Orphan, and this Fellow was my Guardian, ay, ay, I was glad to consent to that Man to come to London. He had the Disposal of me then. If I had not agreed to that, I might have been bound Prentice to a Felt-maker in Shrewsbury; this Fellow would have bound me to a Maker of Felts.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: 'Sheart, and better than to be bound to a Maker of Fops; where, I suppose, you have serv'd your Time; and now you may set up for your self.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: You intend to Travel, Sir, as I'm inform'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Belike i may, Madam. I may chance to sail upon the salt Seas, if my Mind hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Serve or not serve, I shan't ask License of you, Sir; nor the Weather-Cock your Companion. I direct my Discourse to the Lady, Sir; 'Tis like my Aunt may have told you, Madam—Yes, I have settl'd my Concerns, I may say now, and am minded to see Foreign Parts. If an how that the Peace holds, whereby that is Taxes abate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I thought you had design'd for France at all Ad∣ventures.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I can't tell that; 'tis like I may, and 'tis like I may not. I am somewhat dainty in making a Resolution,—because when I make it I keep it. I don't stand shill I, shall I, then; if I say't, I'll do't: But I have Thoughts to tarry a small matter in Town, to learn somewhat of your Lingo first, before I crose the Seas. I'd gladly have a spice of your French as they say, where∣by to hold Discourse in Foreign Countries.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Here is an Academy in Town for that use.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: There is? 'Tis like there may.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: No doubt you will return very much improv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Yes, resin'd like a Dutch Skipper from a Whale-fishing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Nephew, you are welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Aunt, your Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Sir Willfull, your most fathful Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Cousin Fainall, give me your Hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Cousin Witwod, your Servant; Mr Petulant, your Servant.—Nephew, you are welcome again. Will you drink any Thing after your Journey, Nephew, before you cat? Dinner's almost ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I'm very well I thank you, Aunt—However, I thank you for your courtcous Offer. 'Shart I was afraid you wou'd have been in the Fashion too, and have remember'd to have for∣got your Relations. Here's your Cousin Tony, belike, I may'nt call him Brother for fear of Offence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
O he's a Rallier, Nephew—My Cousin's a Wit. And your great Wits always rally their best Friends to chuse.
When you have been aroad, Nephew, you'll understand Raille∣ry better.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Why then let him hold his Tongue in the mean Time; and rail when that Day comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Minc.
SP.P: Mem, I come to acquaint your Laship that Dinner is impatient.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Impatient? Why then belike it won't slay 'till I pull off my Boots. Sweet-heart can you help me to a pain of Slipprs? —My Man's with his Hoss, I warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Fie, fie, Nephew, you wou'd not pull off your Boots here—Go down into the Hall—Dinne shall stay for you —My Nephew's a little unbred, you'll pardon him, Madam —Gentleman will you walk. Mrwood.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I'll follow you. Madam—Before Sir Willfull is ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Why then Foible's a Bawd, an Errant, Rank, Match∣making Bawd. And I it seem am a Husband, a Rank-Husband; and my Wife a very Errant, Rank-Wife,—all in the Way of the World. 'Sdeath to be an Anicipatd Cuckold, a Cuckold in Em∣brio? Sure I was born with budding Antlers like a young Satyr, or a Citizen's Child. 'Sdeath to be Out-witted, to be Out-jilted —Out-Matrimony'd,—If I had kept my Speed like a Stag, 'twere somewhat,—but to crawlafter, with my Horns like a Snail, and be out-strip'd by my Wife—'tis Scurvy Wedlock.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Mar.
SP.P: Then shake it off, you have often wish'd for an Opportunity to part;—and now you have it. But first pre∣vent their Plot,—the half of Millmam's Fortune is too Con∣siderable to be parted with, to a Foe, to Mrabell.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Dam him, that had been mine—had you not made that fond Discovery—That had been forfeitd, had they been Married. My Wife had added Lustre to my Horns, by that En∣crease of Fortune,—I cou'd have worn 'em tipt with Gold, tho' my Forchead had been furnish'd like a Deputy- Hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: They may prove a Cap of Maintenace to you still, if you can away with your Wife. And she's no wors then when you had her—I dare swear she had given up her Game, before she was Marry'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Hum! That may be—She might throw up her Cards; but I'll be hang'd if she did not put Pam in her Pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: You Married her to keep you; and if you can contrive to have her keep you bette than you expected; why should you not keep her longer than you intended?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: The Means, the Means.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Discover to my Lady your Wife's Conduct; threaten to part with her—My Lady loves her, and will come to any Composition to save her Reputation, take the Opportunity of breaking it, just upon the Discovery of this Imposture. My La∣dy will be enrag'd beyond Bounds, and sacrisice Neice, and For∣tune, and all at that Conjucture. And let me alone to keep her warm, if she shou'd flag in her part, I will not fail to prompt her.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Faith this has an Appearance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I'm sorry I hinted to my Lady to endeavour a Match between Millamant and Sir Willfull, that may be an Obstacle.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: O, for that matter leave me to manage him; I'll disable him for that, he will dirnk like a Dane: After Dinner, I'll set his Hand in.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Well, how do you stand affected towards your Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Why faith I'm thinking of it.—Let me see—I am marry'd already; so that's over,—My Wife has plaid the Jade with me—Well, that's over too—I never lov'd her, or if I had, why that wou'd have been over too by this time— Jealous of her I cannot be, for I am certain; so there's an end of Jealousie. Weary of her, I am, and shall be—No, there's no end of that; No, no, that were too much to hope. Thus far concerning my Repose. Now for my Reputation,—As to my own, I marry'd not for it; so that's out of the Question. —And as to my Part in my Wife's—Why she had part∣ed with hers before; so bringing none to me, she can take none from me; 'tis against all rule of Play, that I should lose to one, who has not wherewith. I to stake.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Besides you forget, Marriage is honourable.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Hum! Faith and that's well thought on; Marriage is honourable as you say; and if so, wereore should Cucol∣dom be a Discredit, being deriv'd from to honourable a Root?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Na; I know not; if the Root be Honourable, why not the Branches?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: So, so why this Point's clear,—Well, how do we proceed?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P:
I will contrive a Letter which shall be deliver'd to my Lady at the time when that Rascal who is to act Sir Rowland is with her. It shall come as from an unknown Hand—for the less I appear to know of the Truth—the better I can play the Incendiary. Besides, I would not have Foible provok'd if I cou'd help it,—because you know she knows some Passages—
Nay I expect all will come out—But let the Mine be sprung first, and then I care not if I'm discover'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: If the worst come to the worst,—I'll turn my Wife to Grass—I have already a Deed of Settlement of the best Part of her Estate; which I wheadl'd out of her, and that you shall par∣take at lcast.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I hope you are convine'd that I have Mirabell, now you'll be no more Jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Jealous, no,—by this Kiss—let Husbands be Jealous; but let the Lover still believe. Or if he doubt, let it be only to endear his Pleasure, and prepare the Joy that follows, when he proves his Mistress true, but let Husbands Doubts convert to endless Jealousie; or if they have Belief, let it corrupt to Super∣stition and blind Credulity. I am single; and will herd no more with 'em. True, I wear the Badge, but I'll disown the Order. And since I take my Leave of em, I care not if I Leave 'em a common Motto to their common Crest.

DIV1.L: All Husbands must, or 'Pain or Shame, dure;
The Wife too ealous are, Fools to secure.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT IV. SCENE I.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Is Sir Rowland coming say' thou, Foible? and are things in Order?

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
Lady.
SP.P: Have you pullvill'd the Coachman and pos∣ision, that they may not stink of the Stable, when Sir Rowland comes by?

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Yes, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: And are the Dancers and the Musick ready, that he may be entertain'd in all Points with Correspondence to his Passion?

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: All is ready, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: And—well—and how do I look, Foible?

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Most killing well, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
Well, and how shall I receive him? In what figure shall
I give his Heart the first Impression? There is a grat at deal in the first Impression. Shall I sit?—No, I won't sit—I'll walk— ay I'll walk from the Door upon his Entrance; and then turn full upon him—No, that will be too sudden. I'll lye—ay, I'll lye down—I'll receive him in my little Drssing Room, there's a Couch —Yes, yes, Ill give the first Impression on a Couch—I won't lye neither, but loll and lean upon one Elbow; with one Foot a little dangling off, jogging in a thoughrful way—Yes—and then as soon as he appears, start, ay, start and be surpriz'd and rise to meet him in a pretty Disorder—Yes—O, nothing is more al∣luring than a Leave from a Couch in some Confusion—It shews the Foot to advantage, and furnishes with Blushes, and re com∣posing Airs beyond Comparition. Hark! There's Coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: 'Tis he, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O dear, has my Nephew made his Addresses to Milla∣mant? I order'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Sir Wilfull is set into Drinking, Madam, in the Parlorur.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Ods my Life, I'll send him to her. Call her down, foi∣ble; bring here hither. I'll send him as I go—- When they are together, then come to me Foible, that I may not be too long alone with Sir Rowland.
SP.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Millamant, and Mrs. Fainall.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Madam, I stay'd here, to tell your Ladiship that Mr. Mi∣rabell has waited this half Hour for an Opportunity to talk with you. Tho' my Lady's Orders were to leave you and Sir Willfull together. Shall I tell Mr Mirabell that you are at leisure?

SP.SPEAKER: Mill.
SP.L: There never yet was Woman made,
Nor shall, but to be cours'd.
SP.P: That's hard!

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: You are very fond of Sir John Suckling to day, Milla∣lamant, and the Poets.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: He? Ay, and filthy Verses—So I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Sir Willfull is coming, Madam. Shall I send Mr. Mira∣bell away?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Ay, if you please, Foible, send him away,—Or send him hither,—just as you will dear Foible.—I think I'll see him—Shall I? Ay, let the Wretch come Repeating.] Thyrsis. a Youth of the Inspir'd Train.

DIV3.P: Dear Fainall, entertain Sir Willfull—Thou hast Philosophy to un∣dergo a Fool, thou art marry'd and hast Patience—I would con∣ser with my own Thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: I am oblig'd to you that you would make me your Proxy in this Affair; but I have Busines of my own.

DIV3.P: O Sir Willfull; you are come at the Critical Instant. There's your Mistress up to the Ears in Love and Contemplation, pursue your Point, now or never.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Yes, my Aunt will have it so,—I would gladly have been encoruragd with a Bottle or two, This while Milla. walks about Re∣peating to her self. because I'm somewhat wary at first, before I am acquainted;—But I hope, after a time, I shall break my Mind—that is upon further Acquaintance—So for the Present, Cousin I'll take my leave— If so be you'll be so kind to make my Excuse I'll return to my Company—

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: O fie, Sir Willfull! What, you must not be Daunted.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Daunted, no that's not it, it is not so much for that—for if so be that I st on't, I'll dot. But only for the present, 'tis sufficrent'till further Acquaintance, that's all—your Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Nay, I'll swear you shall never lose se favourable an Op∣potunity, if I can help it. I'll leave you together and lock the Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Nay, nay Cousin,—I have forgot my Gloves,— What d'ye do? 'Shart a has' lock'd the Door indeed, I think— Nay, Cousin Fainall, open the Door—Pshaw, what a Vixon Trick is this?—Nay, now a' has seen me too—Cousin, I made bold to pass thro' as it were—I think this Door's In∣chanted—

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: [Repeating.] I pritbee spare me, gentle Boy, Press me no more for that slight Toy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Anan? Cousin, your Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: —That foolish Trisle of a Heart—Sir Willfull!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Yes,—your Servant. No Offence I hope, Cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla
SP.P: [Repeating] I swear it will not do its part, Tho' thou do'st thine, employ'st thy Power and Art.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Anaa? Suckling? No such Suckling neither, Cousin, nor Stripling: I thank Heav'n I'm no Minor.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Ah Rustick! ruder than Gothick.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, well, I shall understand your Lingo one of these Days, Cousin, in the mean while I must answer in plain English.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Have you any Business with me, Sir Willfull?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Not at present, Cousin,—Yes, I made bold to see, to come and know if that how you were dispos'd to fetch a Walk this Evening, if so be that I might not be troublesome, I would have fought a Walk with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: A Walk? What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Nay nothing—Only for the Walks sake, that's all—

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: I nausate Walking; 'tis a Country Diversion, I loath the Country and every thing that relates to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Indeed! Hah! Look ye, look ye, you do? Nay, 'tis like you may—Here are choince of Pastimes here in Town, as Plays and the like, that must be consess'd indeed.—

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Ah l'etourdie! I hate the Town too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Dear Heart, that's much—Hah! that you should hate 'em both! Hah! 'tis like you may; there are some can't relish the Town, and others, can'ts away with the Country,—'tis like you may be one of those, Cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha. Yes, tis like I may.—You have no∣thing further to say to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Not at present, Cousin.—'Tis like when I have an Opportunity to be more private,—I may break my Mind in some measure,—I conjecture you partly guess—How∣ever that's as time shall try,—But spare to speak and spare to seed, as they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: If it is of no great Improtance, Sir Willfull, you will oblige me to leave me: I have just now a little Business.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Enough, enough, Cousin: Yes, yes all a case— When you're dispos'd when you're dispos'd. Now's as well as another time; and another time as well as now. All's one for that, — Yes, yes, if your Concerns call you, there's no haste; it will keep cold as they say,—Cousin, your Servant.— I think this Door's lock'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: You may go this way, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Your Servant, then with your leave I'll return to my Company.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Ay, ay; ha, ha, ha.
Like Phoebus sung the n less am'ros Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: —Like Daphne she, as Lovely and as Coy. Do you lock your self up from me to make my Search more Cu∣rious? Or is this pretty Artifice contriv'd, to signifie that here the Chance must end, and my pursuit be Crown'd, for you can fly no further.—

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Vanity! No—I'll fly and be follow'd to the last Moment, tho'I am upon the very Verge of Matrimony, I expect you shou'd sollicit me as much as if I were wavering at the Grate of a Monastery, with one Foot over the Threshold. I'll be solli∣cited to the very last, nay and afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: What, after the last?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: O, I should think I was poor and had nothing to besow, If I were redue'd to an inglorious Ease; and free'd from the agreea∣bel Fatigues of Sollicitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: But do not you know, that when Favours are conferr'd upon instant and tedious Sollicitation, that they dimmh in their Value, and that both the Giver loses the Grac, and the Receiv∣er lessens his Pleasure?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: It may be in Things of common Application; but never sure in Love. O, I hate a Lover, that can dare to think, he draws a Moments Air, Independent on the Bounty of . There is not so impudent a Thing in Nature, as the sawey Look of an assured Man, Consident of Succes. The Pedan Arrogance of a very Husband, has not so Pragmatical an Air. Ah! I'll ne∣ver marry, unless I am first made sure of my Will and Pleasure. Mira. Wou'd you have 'em both before Marriage? Or will you be contented with the first now, and stay for the other 'till after Grace?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Ah don't be Impertinent—My dear Liberty, shall I leave the? My faithful Soude, my darling Contemplation, must I bid you then Adu? Ay-h adie—My morning Thoughts, agreeable Walkings all ye , ye —I can't 'tis more than im∣possible —Positively Mirabell, I'll lye a Bed in a Morning as long as I Please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Then I'll get up in a Morning as early as I please.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Ah! Idle Creature, get up when you will—And d'ye hear, I won't be call'd Names after I'm Marry positively I won't be call'd Names.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Names!

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P:
Ay as Wife, Spouse, my Dear, Joy, Jewel, Love, Sweet-heart, and the rest of that Nauseous Cant, in which Men and their Wives are so ulsomely familiar,—I shall never bear that,—Good Mirabell don't let us be familiar or fond, nor kiss before Folks, like my Lady Fadr and Sir Francis: Nor go to Hide-Park together the first Sunday in a new Chariot, to Provoke Eyes and Whispesr; And then never to be seen there
together again; as if we were proud of one another the first Week, and asham'd of one another ever after. Let us never Vi∣sit together, nor go to a Play together, but let us be very strange and well bred: Let us be as strange as if we had been marry'd a great while; and as well bred as if we were not marry'd at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Have you any more Conditions to offer? Hitherto your Demands are pretty reasonable.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Triss,—As Liberty to pay and receive Visits to and from whom I please; to write and receive Letters, without Interrogatories or wry Faces on your Part; to wear what I Please; and chuse Conversation with regard only to my own Taste; to have no Obligation upon me to converse with Wits that I don't like, because they are your Acqaintance; or to be in∣timate with Fools, because they may be your Relations. Come to Dinner when I please, dine in my dresling Room when I'm out of Humour without giving a Reason. To have my Closet In∣violate; to be sole Empres of my Tea-Table, which you must never presume to approach without first asking leave. And last∣ly, where-ever I am, you shall always knock at the Door before you come in. These Articles subscrib'd, if I continue to endure you a little longer, I may be degrees dwindle into a Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Your Bill of Fare is something advanc'd in this latter Ac∣count. Well, have I Liberty to offer Conditions—That when you are dwindl'd into a Wife, I may not be beyond Measure enlarg'd into a Husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: You have free leave; propose your utmost, speak and spare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I thank you. Inprimis then, I Covenant that your Ac∣quaintance be general; that you admit no sworn Confident, or Intimate of your own Sex; no she Friend to skreen her Affairs under your Cuntenance, and tempt you to make Trial of a Mutual Se∣cresie. No Decoy-Duck to wheadle you a fop—sorambling to the Play in Mask—Then bring you home in a pretend∣ed fright, when you think you shall be found out.—And rail at me for missing the Play, and disappointing the Frolick which you had to pick me up and prove my Constancy.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Destable Inprimis! I go to the Play in a Mask!

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P:
Item, I Article, that you continue to like your own Face, as long as I shall. And while it passes Currant with me, that you endeavour not to new Coin it. To which end, together with all Vizards for the Day, I Prohibit all Masks for the Night, made of oild-skinsand I know not what—Hog's-bones, Hare's-gall,
Pig-water, and the Marrow of a ro sted Car. In short, I forbid all Commerce with the Gentlewomen in what call-it-Court. Item, I shut my Do all with Baskets, and penny-worths of China, Fans, &c.—Item when you shall be Breeding.—

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Ah! Nam it not.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Which may be presum'd, with a Blassing on our Endea∣vours—

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Odious Endeavovrs!

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I denounce ag all strait-Lacing, Squeezing for a Shape, 'till you mould my Boy's Hd like a Sugar-loa, and in stead of a Man-Child, make me the Father to -billet Lastly, to the Dommion of the Tea-Table I submit.—But with proviso, that you exceed not in your Province; but restrain your self to native and simple Tea-Table Drinks, as Tea, Choco∣late and Coffee. As likewise to Ge and Authoriz'd Tea-Table Talk,—such as mending of Fashions spoting Reputations, railing at absent Friends, and so forth—But that on no Ac∣count you encroach upon the Mens Prerogative, and presume to drink Healths, or toast Fellows, for prevention of which, I banish all Foreign Forces, all Auxiliaries to the Tea-Table, as Orange-Brandy, all Anmseed, Con, Citron and Barbado's-Waters, to∣gether with Ratasia and the most Spirit of Clary,—But for Cousip-Wine -Water and all Dormitives, those I allow, —These Proviso's! admitted, in other things I may prove a tractable and complying Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: O horrd proviso's! lthy strong Waters; I toast Fellows, Odious Men! I hate your odious proviso's.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Then were agreed. Shall I kiss your Hand upon the Contract? and here comes one to be a Witness to the Sealing of the Deed.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Fainall, what shall I do? shall I have him? I think I must have him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Ay, ay, take him, take him, what shou'd you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Well then—I'll take my Death I'm in a horrid Fright—Fainall, I shall never say it—Well—I think— I'll endure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Fy, fy, have him, have him, and tell him so in plain Terms: For I am sure you have a mind to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P:
Are you? I think I have—and the horrid Man looks as if he thought so too—Well, you ridiculous thing
you, I'll have you,—I won't be kis'd, nor I won't be thank'd— Here kis my Hand tho'—So hold your Tongue now, and don't say a word.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Mirabell, there's a Necessity for your Obedience; —You have neither time to talk nor stay. My Mother is coming; and in my Conscience if the shou'd see you, wou'd fall into Fits, and may be not recover time enough to Return to Sir Rowland, who as Foible tells me is in a fair Way to succeed. Therefore spare your Extacies for another Occasion, and slip down the back-Stairs, where Foible waits to consult you.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Ay, go, go. In the mean time I suppose you have said something to please me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: I am all Obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Yonder Sir Willfull's drunk; and so noisie that my Mother has been forc'd to leave Sir Rowland to appease him; but he answers her only with Singing and Drinking—what they have done by this time I know not. But Petulant and he were upon quarrelling as I came by.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Well, if Mirabell thou'd not make a good Husband, I am a lost thing;—for I find I love him viloently.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: So it seems, when you mind not what's said to you. —If you doubt him, you had best take up with Sir Willfull.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: How can you name that superannuated Lubber? foh!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: So, is the Fray made up, that you have left 'em?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Left 'em? I could stay no longer— have laugh'd like ten Christnings—I am tipsie with laughing—If I had staid any longer I should have urst,—I must have been let out and piec'd in the Sides like and unsiz'd Camlet—Yes, yes, th Fray is compos'd; my Lady came in like a and stopt their Proceedings.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: What was the Dispute?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: That's the Jest, there was no Dispute, they cou'd nei∣ther of 'em speak for Rage; and so fell a sputt'ring at one ano∣ther like two roasting Apples.

DIV3.P: Now , all's over, all's well; Gad my Head begins to whim it about—Why dost thou not speak? thou art both as drunk and as mute as a Fih.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Look you, Mrs. Millamant—If you can love me, dear Nymph—ay it—and that's the Conclusion—pass on, or pass off,—that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P:
Thou hast utter'd Volumes, Folio's, in less than Decimo
Sexto, my dear , Sirrah Petulant, thoa art an Ep∣tomizer of Words.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: —You are an Annihilator of Sense.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Thou art a Retailer of and dost deal in of Remnans, like a Maker of Pineushions—thou truth (metaphorcally speaking) a Speaker of short-hand

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: I without a figure) just one half of an A and woud yonder, thy half Brother is the rest—A of Asses sp, would make just four of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Thou dost bite, my dear kiss me for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Stand oil—I'll kiss no more Males,—I have kid your twin yonder in a humour of Reoniliation, 'till he () rises upon my Stomach like a Radish.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Eh! filthy Creature—what was the Quarrel?

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: There was no Quarrel—there might have been a Quarrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: If there had been Words between 'em to have ex∣press'd Provocation, they had gone together by the ars like a pair of Castants.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: You were the Quarrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Me!

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: If I have a Humour to quarrel, I can make less Matters conclude Premises,—If you are not handsom, what thn? If I have a Humour to prove it.—If I shall have my Reward, say so; if not, ight for your Face the next time your self—I'll go sleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Do, wrap thy self up like a Wood-louse and dream Revenge —And hear me, if thou canst learn to write by to Morrow Morning, pn me a Challenge—I'll carry it for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: Carry your Mistres's Monkey a Spider—go lea Dogs, and read Romances—I'll go to bed to my

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: He's horridly drunk—how came you all in this Pickle?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: A Plot, a Plot, to get rid of the Knight,—Your Hus∣band's Advice; but he snea'd off.
SP.STAGE: Enter Lady, and Sir Willfull drunk.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Out upon't out upon't at Years of Dicration, and comport your self at this Rantipole rate.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: No Offence, Aunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady
SP.P: Offe nce? As I'm a Person, I'm asham'd of you— Fogh! how you stink of Wine! D'ye think my Nie will over en Borachio! you're an absolute Borachio.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Borachio!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: At a time when you shou'd commence an Amour, and put your best Foot foremost—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir will.
SP.P: 'Sheart, an you grutch me your Liquor, make a Bill —Give me more Drink, and take my Purse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sings.
SP.L: 'Pr: tee fill me the Glass
'Till it Laughs in my Face,
With Ale that is 'Potent and Mellow;
He that whines for a Lass
Is an iganorant Ass,
For a Bumper has not its Fellow.
SP.P: But if you wou'd have me marry my Cousin, das—say the Word, and I'll do't—Willfull will do't that's the Word—willfull will do't, that's my Crest—my Motto I have forgot.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My Nephew's a little overtaken, Cousin—but 'tis with drinking your Healh—O' my Word you are oblig'd to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: In Vino Veritas, Aunt:—If I drunk your Health to day, Cousin,—I am a Borachio. But if you have a Mind to be marry'd say the Word, and send for the Piper, Willfull will do't. If not, dust it away, and let's have t'other Round— Tony, Ods-heart where's Tony—Tony's and honest Fellow, but he spits after a Bumper, and that's a Fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Sings.
SP.L: We'll drink and we'll never ba' done Boys,
Put the Glass then around with the Sun Boys,
Let Apollo's Example invite us;
For he's drunk ev'ry Night,
And that makes him so bright,
That he's able next Morning to light us.
SP.P: The Sun's a good Pimple, and honest Soaker, he has Cellar at your . If I travel, Aunt, I touch at your Antipodes— your Antipodes are a good rascally sort of topsi turvy Fellows— If I had a Bumper I'd stand upon my Head and drink a Health to 'em—A Match or no Match, Cousin, with the hard Name, —Aunt, Willfull will do't. If she has her aidenhead let her look to't,—if the has not, let her keep her own Counsel in the mean time, and cry out at the Nine Months End.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Your Pardon, Madam. I can stay no longer—Sir Willfull grows very powerful, Egh! how he smells I shall be o∣vercome if I stay. Come Cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
Smells! he would poison a Tallow-Chandler and his Family. Beastly Creature, I know not what to do with him.—
Travel quoth a; ay travel, travel, get thee gone, get thee but far enough, to the Saracens, or the Tartars, or the Turks—for thou art not sit to live in a Christian Commonwealth, thou

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will
SP.P: Turks, no; no Turks. Aunt; Your Turks are Insidels, and believe not in the Grape Your a, your man is adry Skard.—No Ofence, Aunt My Map says that your Turk is not so honest a Man as your Ch—I cannot find by the Map that your is Othod—Where∣by it is a plain Case, that Orthodox is a hard Word, Aunt, and (hiccup) Greek for Claret.

SP.SPEAKER: Sings.
SP.L: To drink is a Christian Drversion,
Unknown to the Turk and the Persan
Let Mahometan Fools
liue by Heatbenb Rules
And be damn'd over 'Iea-Cups and Coffee
But let British Lads sing,
Crown a Health to the King,
And a ig for your Sultan and Sophy.
Ah, Tony!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Sir Rowland impatient? Good lack! what shall I do with this beastly Tumbril? Go lye down and sleep, you Sot—Or as I'm a Person, I'll have you bastmado'd with Broom-sticks. Call up the W.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Ahey? Wenches, where are the Wenches?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Dear Cousin get him away, and you will bind me to you mly. I have an Affair of moment that invades me with some Pracipitation—You will oblige me to all Futurity.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Come, Knight—Pox on him, I don't know what to say to him—Will you to a Cock-match?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will
SP.P: With a Wench, Tony? Is she a shake-bag, Sirrah? let me bite your Check for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Horrible! He has a Breath like a Bagpipe—Ay, ay, come will you march, my Salopan?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir will.
SP.P: Lead on, little Tony—I'll follow thee my Anthony, my Tantony, Sirrah thou sha't be my Tantony, and I'll by thy Pig.
—And a Fig for your Sultan and Sophy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: This will never do. It will never make a Match.— At least before he has been abroad.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Waitwell, disguis'd as for Sir Rowland.
DIV3.P: Dear Sir Rowland, I am confounded with Confusion at the Retrospection of my own Rudeness,—I have more Pardone to ask than the 'Pope distributes in the Year of Jubilec. but I hope where there is likely to be so near an Alliance,—we may un∣bend the Severity of Decorum—and dispense with a little Ce∣remony.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: My Impatience, Madam, is the Effect of my Transport; —and 'till I have the Fossession of your a orale Person, I am tantaliz'd on the Rack; and do but hang, Maam, on the Ten∣ter of Expectation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: you have Excess of Gallantry, Sir Rowland; and press things to a Conclusion, with a most prevailing V. hemence.— But a Day or two for Decency of Marriage.—

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: For Decency of Funeral, Madam. The Delay will break my heart—or if that should fail, I shall be Poison'd My Nephew will get an inkhng of my Designs, and Poison me,— and I would willingly starve him before I die—I would gladly go out of the World with that Satisfaction.—That would be some Comfort to mo if I could but live so long as to be reveng'd on that unnatural Viper.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Is he so Unatural, say you? Truly I would contribute much both to the saving of your Life, and the accomplishment of your Revenge—Not that I respect my self; tho' he has been a perfidious Wretch to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Persidious to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O sir Rowland, the Hours that he has dy'd away at my Fect, the Tears that he has shed, the Oaths that he has set'worn, the Palpitations that he has felt, the Trances and the Tremblings, the Ardors and the Estacies, the Kneelings and the Risings, the Heart-heavings and the Hand-gripings, the Pangs and the Pathetick Regards of his protesting Eyes! Oh no Memory can Register.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: What, my Rival! is the Rebel my Rival? a'dies.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: No, don't kill him at once, Sir Rowland, starve him gradually Inch by Inch.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: I'll do't. In three Weeks he shall be bare-foot; in a Month out a Knees with begging an Alms,—he shall starve upward and upward, 'till he has nothing living but his Head, and then go out in a Stink like a Candle's End upon a Save all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
Well, Sir Rowaland, you have the way—You are no Novice in the Labyrinth of Love—You have the Clue—
But as I am a Person, Sir Rowland, you must not attribute my yielding to any finister Appetite, or Indigestion of Widow-hood; nor impute my Complacency to any Lethargy of Continence—I hope you do not think me prone to any Iteration of Nuptials.—

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Far be it from me—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: If you do. I protest I must recede—or think that I have made a Prostitution of Decorums, but in the Vhmence of Compon, and to save the Life of a Person of so much Im∣portance —

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: I esteem it so—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Or else you wrong my Condesion—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: indeed you do.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: I do not, I do not—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I do not, fair Shrine of Virture.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: If you think the least Scruple of Carnality was an Ingre∣dient —

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Dear Madam, no You are all Comphire and Frankin∣cense, all Chastity and Odour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Or that—

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Madam, the Dancers are ready, and there's one with a Litter, who must deliver it into your own Hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Sir Rowland, will you give me leave? Think favourably, judge candidly, and conclude you have found a Person who would fuster Racks in Honour's Cause, dear Sir Rowland, and will wait on you ntly.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Fie, fie!—What a Slavery have I undergone; spouse, hast thou any Cordial—I want Spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: What a washy Rogue art thou, to pant thus for a Quar∣ter of an Hours Lying and Swearing to a fine Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: O, she is the Antidote to Desire. Spouse thou will't fare the worse for't—I shall have no Appetite to Interation of Nuptials—this Eight and Forty Hours—By this Hand I'd rather be a Chair-man in the Dog-days—than act Sir Rowland 'till this time to Morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Call in the Dancers,—Sir Rowland, we'll sit. if you please, and see the Entertainment.

Now with your Prmission, Sir Rowland, I will peruse my Let∣ter —I would open it in your Presence, because I would not make you uneasie. If it should make you uneasie I would burn it— speak if it does—but you may see by the Superscription it is like a Woman's Hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: By Heav'n! Mrs. Marwood's, I know it,—my Heart akes—get it from her—

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: A Woman's Hand? No, Madam, that's no Woman's Hand, I see that already. That's some Body whose Throat must be cut.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Nay, Sir Rowland, since you give me a Proof of your Passion by your Jealousie, I promise you I'll make you a Return, by a frank Communication—You shall see it—we'll open it together—look you here.

DIV3.P: Reads.—Madam, tho' unknown to you, [Look you there, 'tis from no Body that I know.]—I have that Honour for your Character, that I think my self oblig'd to let you know you are abus'd. He who pretends to be Sir Row∣land is a Cheat and a Rascal.—

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Unfortunate, all's ruin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: How, how, let me see, let me see—reading, A Rascal and disguis'd, and subborn'd for that Imposture,—O Villany! O Villany!—by the Contrivance of—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I shall aint, I shall die, oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Say 'tis your Nephew's Hand.—Quickly, his Plot, swear, swear it.—

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Here's a Villain! Madam, don't you perceive it, don't you see it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Too well, too well I have seen too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: I told you at first I knew the Hand;—A Woman's Hand? The Rascal writes a sort of a large Hand; your Roman Hand—I saw there was a Throat to be cut presentely. If he were my Son, as he is my Nephew, I'd Pistol him—

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: O Treachery! But are you sure, Sir Rowland, it is his Writing?

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Sure? am I here? do I live? do I love this Pearl of In∣dia? I have Twenty Letters in my Pocket from him, in the same Character.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: O what Luck it is, Sir Rowland, that you were present at this Juncture! This was the Business that brought Mr. Mi∣rabell disguis'd to Madam Millamant this Afternoon. I thought something was contriving, when he stole by me and would have hid his Face.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: How, how!—I heard the Villain was in the House indeed, and now I remember, my Niece went away abruptly, when Sir Willfull was to have made his Addresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Then, then Madam, Mr. Mirabell waited for her in her Chamber, but I wou'd not tell your Ladyship to discompose you when you were to receive Sir Rowland.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Enough, his Date is short.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: No, good Sir Rowland, don't incur the Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Law! I care not for Law. I can but die, and 'tis in a good Cause—My Lady shall be satisfy'd of my Truth and In∣nocence, tho' it cost me my Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: No, dear Sir Rowland, don't ight, if you shou'd be kill'd I must never shew my Face; or hang'd,—O Consider my Reputation, Sir Rowland—No you shan't fight,—I'll go in and examine my Niece; I'll make her confess. I conjure you Sir Rowland by all your Love not to fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: I am charm'd Madam, I obey. But some Proof you must let me give you;—I'll go for a black Box, which con∣tains the Writings of my whole Estate, and deliver that into your Hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Ay dear Sir Rowland, that will be some Comfort, bring the black Box.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: And may I presume to bring a Contract to be sign'd this Night? May I hope so far?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Bring what you will; but come alive, pray come alive. O this is a happy Discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: Dead or alive I'll come—and married we will be in spight of Treachery, ay and get an Heir that shall defeat the last remaining Glimpse of Hope in my abandon'd Nephew. Come, my Buxom Widow.

DIV3.L: E'er long you shall substantial Proof receive

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Or arrant Knave.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT V. SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: [Scene Continues.] Enter Lady Wishfort and Foible.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
OUT of my House, out of my House, thou Viper, thou Serpent, that I have foster'd, thoub bosom Trai∣tress, that I rais'd from nothing—Begon begon, begon, go, go, —That I took from washing of old Gause and weaving of dead
Hair, with a bleak blue Nose, over a Chasing-dish of starv'd Embers, and Dining behind a Traver's Rag, in a Shop no bigger than a Bird-cage,—go, go, strave again, do, do.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Dear Madam, I'd beg Pardon on my Knevs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Away, out, out, go set up for your self again—do, drive a Trade, do, with your Three penny Worth of small Ware, slaunting upon a Packthread, under. Brandy-sellers Bulk, or a∣gainst a dead Wall by a Ballad-monger. Go, hang out an old Frisoner-gorget, with a Yard of Yellow Colberteen again; do; an old gnaw'd Mask, Two Rows of Pins and Child's Fiddle; A Glass Necklace with the Beads broken, and a Quilted Night∣cap with one Ear. Go, go, drive a Trade,——These were your Commodoties, you treacherous Trull, this was your Mer∣chandize you dealt in, when I took you into my House, plac'd you next my self, and made you Governante of my whole Fa∣mily. You have forgot this, have you? Now you have feather'd your Nest.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: No, no, dear Madam. Do but hear me, have but a Mo∣ment's Patience—I'll confess all. Mr. Mirabell seduc'd me; I am not the first that he has wheadl'd with his dissembling Tongue; Your Ladiship's own Wisdom has been deluded by him, then how shou'd I, a poor Ignorant, defend my self? O Madam, If you knew but what he promis'd me; and how he assur'd me your La∣diship shou'd come to no Damage—Or else the Wealth of the Indies shou'd not have brib'd me to conspire against so Good, so Sweet, so kind a Lady as you have been to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: No Damage? What to betray me, to marry me to a Cast-serving-Man; to make me a Receptacle, an Hospital for a decay'd Pimp? No Damage? O thou frontless Impudence, more than a big-belly'd Actress.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Pray do but hear me Madam, he cou'd not marry your Ladiship, Madam—No indeed his Marriage was to have been void in Law; for he was marry'd to me first, to secure your La∣diship. He cou'd not have bedded your Ladiship; for if he had consummated with your Ladiship, he must have run the risque of the Law, and been put upon his Clergy—Yes indeed, I en∣quir'd of the Law in that case before I wou'd meddle or make.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
What, then I have been your Property, have I? I have been convenient to you it seems;—while you were catering for Mirabell; I have been Broaker for you? What, have you made a passive Bawd of me?—this exceeds all Precedent; I am brought to fine Uses, to become a Botcher of second-hand Mar∣riages,
between Abigails and Andrews! I'll coupl you. Yes, I'll baste you together, you and your Philander. I'll Dukes-'Place you, as I'm a Person. Your Tuttle is in Custody already: You shall Coo in the same Cage, if there be Constable or Warrant in the Parish.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: O that ever I was born, O that I was ever marry'd,— a Bride, ay I shall be a Birdewell-Bride. Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Poor Foible, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: O Madam, my Lady's gone for a Constable; I shall be had to a Justice, and put to Bridewell to beat Hemp; poor Wait∣well's gone to Prison already.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Have a good Heart, Foible, Mirabell's gone to give Security for him, this is all Marwood's and my Husband's doing.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Yes, yes; I know it, Madam, she was in my Lady's Closet, and over-heard all that you said to me before Dinner. She sent the Letter to my Lady, and that missing Effect, Mr. Fainall laid this Plot to arrest Waitwell, when he pretended to go for the Papers; and in the mean time Mrs. Marwood declar'd all to my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Was there no Mention made of me in the Letter? —My Mother does not suspect my being in the Confederacy? I fancy Marwood has not told her, tho' she has told my Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Yes, Madam; but my Lady did not see that Part: We stifled the Letter before she read so far. Has that mischievous De∣vil told Mr. Fainall of your Ladiship then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Ay, all's out, my Affair with Mirabell, every thing discover'd. This is the last Day of our living together, that's my Comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Indeed Madam, and so 'tis a Comfort if you knew all,— he has been even with your Ladiship; which I cou'd have told you long enough since, but I love to keep Peace and Quietness by my good Will: I had rather bring Friends together, than set 'em at Distance. But Mrs. Marwood and he are nearer related than ever their Parents thought for.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Say's it thou so Foible? Canst thou prove this?

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P:
I can take my Oath of it, Madam, so can Mrs. Mincing; we have had many a fair Word from Madam Marwood, to con∣ceal something that pass'd in our Chamber one Evening when you were at Hide-Park;—and we were thought to have gone a Walking: But we went up unawares,—tho' we were sworn to Secrefie too; Madam Marwood took a Book and swore us upon
it: But it was but a Book of Verses and Poems,—So long as it was not a Bible-Oath, we may break it with a safe Conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: This Discovery is the most opportune Thing I cou'd wish. Now Mincing?

SP.SPEAKER: Minc.
SP.P: My Lady wou'd speak with Mrs. Foible, Mem. Mr. Mi∣rabell is with her; he has set your Spouse at liberty, Mrs. Foible, and wou'd have you hide your self in my Lady's Closet, 'till my old Lady's Anger is abated. O, my old Lady is in a perilous Passion, at something Mr. Fainall has said, he swears, and my old Lady cries. There's a fearful Hurricane I vow. He says Mem; how that he'll have my Lady's Fortune made over to him, or he'll be divorc'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Does your Lady and Mirabell know that?

SP.SPEAKER: Minc.
SP.P: Yes Mem, they have sent me to see if Sir Willfull be sober, and to bring him to them. My Lady is resolv'd to have him I think, rather than lose such a vast Sum as Six Thousand Pound. O, come Mrs. Foible, I hear my old Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Foible, you must tell Mincing, that she must pre∣pare to vouch when I call her.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Yes, yes, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Minc.
SP.P: O yes Mem, I'll vouch any thing for your Ladiship's Ser∣vice, be what it will.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O my dear Friend, how can I enumerate the Benefits that I have receiv'd from your Goodness? To you I owe the time∣ly Discovery of the false Vows of Mirabell; to you the Detecti∣on of the Impostor Sir Rowland. And now you are become an Intercessor with my Son-in-Law, to save the Honour of my House, and compound for the Frailties of my Daughter. Well Friend, You are enough to reconcile me to the bad World, or else I would retire to Desarts and Solitudes; and feed harmless Sheep by Groves and purling Streams. Dear Marwood, let us leave the World, and retire by our selves and be Shepherdesses.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Let us first dispatch the Affair in hand, Madam, we shall have Leisure to think of Retirement afterwards. Here is one who is concern'd in the Treaty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
O Daughter, Daughter, is it possible thou should'st be my Child, Bone of my Bone, and Flesh of my Flesh, and as I may say, another Me, and yet transgress the most minute Particle of severe Virtue? Is it possible you should lean aside to Iniquity, who have been cast in the direct Mold of Virtue? I have not on∣ly
been a Mold but a Pattern for you, and a Model for you, af∣ter you were brought into the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: I don't understand your Ladiship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Not understand? Why have you not been Naught? Have you not been Sophisticated? Not understand? Here I am ruin'd to compound for your Caprices and your Cuckoldoms. I must pawn my Plate and my Jewels, and ruin my Neice, and all little enough—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: I am wrong'd and abus'd, and so are you. Tis a false Accusation, as false as Hell, as false as your Friend there, ay or your Friend's Friend, my false Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: My Friend, Mrs. Fainall? You Husband my Friend, what do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: I know what I mean, Madam, and so do you; and so shall the World at a Time convenient.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: I am sorry to see you so passionate, Madam. More Temper would look more like innocence. But I have done. I am sorry my Zeal to serve your Ladiship and Family, should admit of Misconstruction, or make me liable to Afronts. You will pardon me, Madam, if I meddle no more with an Affair, in which I am not personally concern'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O dear Friend, I am so asham'd that you should meet with such Returns;—You ought to ask Pardon on your Knees, ungrateful Creature; she deserves more from you, than all your Life can accomplish—O don't leave me destitute in this Per∣plexity; —No, stick to me, my good Genius.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: I tell you, Madam, you're abus'd—Stick to you? ay, like a Leach, to suck your best Blood—she'll drop off when she's full. Madam, you shan't pawn a Bodkin, nor part with a Brass Counter, in Composition for me. I desie 'em all. Let 'em prove their Aspersions: I know my own Innocence, and dare stand by a Trial.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
Why, if she shou'd be innocent, if she shou'd be wrong'd after all, ha? I don't know what to think,—and I promise you, her Education has been unexceptionable—I may say it; for I chiefly made it my own Care to initiate her very Infancy in the Rudiments of Virtue, and to impress upon her tender Years a Young Odium and Aversion to the very Sight of Men,—ay Friend, she wou'd ha' shriek'd if she had but seen a Man,'till she was in her Teens. As I'm a Person 'tis true—She was never suffer'd to play with a Male-Child, tho' but in Coats; Nay her very Babies were of the Feminine Gender,—O, she never look'd a
Man in the Face but her own Father, or the Caplain, and him we made a shift to put upon her for a Woman, by the help of his long Garments, and his sleek Face; 'till she was going in her Fifteen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: 'T was much she should be deceiv'd so long.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I warrant you, or she would never have born to have been Catechiz'd by him; and have heard his long Lectures against Singing and Dancing, and such Debaucheries; and going to filthy Plays; and prophane Musick-meetings, where the Lewd Trebles sqeek nothing but Bawdy, and the Bases roar Blasphemy. O, she would have swoon'd at the Sight or Name of an obscene Play¦Book —and can I think after all this, that my Daughter can be Naught? What, a Whore? And thought it Excommunication to set her Foot within the Door of a Play-house. O my dear Friend, I can't believe it, no, no; as she says, let him prove it, let him prove it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Prove it, Madam? What, and have your Name prostituted in a publick Court; yours and your Daughter's Repu∣tation worry'd at the Bar by a Pack of Bawling Lawyers? To be usher'd in with an O Tes of Scandal; and have your Case open'd by an old fumbling Leacher in a Quoif like a Man Mid∣wife, to bring your Daughter's Infamy to Light, to be Theme for legal Punsters, and Quiblers by the Statute; and become a Jest, against a Rule of Court, where there is no Precedent for a Jest in any Record; not even in Dooms-day-Book: To discompose the Gravity of the Bench, and provoke naughty Interrogatories in more naughty Law Latin; while the good Judge tickl'd with the Proceeding, simpers under a Grey Beard, and idges off and on his Cushion as if he had swallow'd Cantharides, or ate upon Cow-Itch.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O, 'tis very hard!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: And then to have my Young Revellers of the Temple take Notes, like Prentices at a Conventicle; and after talk it all over again in Commons, or before Drawers in an Eating-House.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Worse and worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Nay this is nothing; if it would end here 'twere well. But it must after this be consign'd by the Short-hand Wri∣ters to the publick Press; and from thence be transferr'd to the Hands nay into the Thorats and Lungs of Hawkers, with Voices more Licentious than the loud Flounder-man's, or the Woman that cries Grey-Pease; and this you must hear 'till you are stunn'd; nay, you must hear nothing else for some Days.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
O, 'tis insupportable, No, no, dear Friend, make it up, make it up; ay, ay, I'll Compound. I'll give up all, my self and my all, my Nice and her all—any thing, every thing for Composition. Mrs. Mar. Nay, Madam, I advise nothing, I only lay before you, as a Friend, the Inconveniencies which perhaps you have overseen. Here comes Mr. Fainall. If he will be satisfy'd to huddle up all in Silence, I shall be glad. You must think I would rather Congratulate than Condolc with you. Enter Fainall. Lady. Ay, ay, I do not doubt it, dear Marwood: No, no, I do not doubt it. Fain. Well, Madam; I have suffer'd my self to be overcome by the Importunity of this Lady your Friend, and am content you shall enjoy your own proper Estate during Life; on Condi∣tion you oblige your self never to Marry, under such Penalty as I think convenient. Lady. Never to Marry? Fain. No more Sir Rowlands,—the next Imposture may not be so timely detected. Mrs. Mar. That Condition, I dare answer, my Lady will con∣sent to, without Diffculty; she has already but too much expe∣rienc'd the Persidiousness of Men. Besides, Madam, when we retire to our Pastoral Solitude we shall bid diu to all other Thoughts. Lady. Ay, that's true; but in Case of Necessity; as of Health, of some such Emergency— Fain. O, if you are prescrib'd Marriage, you shall be consi∣der'd; I will only reserve to my self the Power to chuse for you. If your Physick be wholsome, it matters not who is your Apo∣thecary. Next, my Wife shall settle on me the Remainder of her Fortune, not made over already; and for her Maintenance depend entirely on my Discretion. Lady. This is most inhumanly Savage; exceeding the Barbari∣ty of a Muscovite Husband. Fain. I learn'd it from his Czarisb Majesty's Retinue, in a Winter Evening's Conference over Brandy and Pepper, amongst other Secrets of Matrimony and Policy, as they are at present pra∣ctis'd in the Northern Hemisphere. But this must be agreed unto, and that positively. Lastly, I will be endow;d in right of my Wife, with that Six Thousand Pound, which is the Moiety of Mrs. Mil∣lamant's Fortune in your Possession: And which she has forfeited (as will appear by the last Will and Testament of your deceas'd
Husband, Sir Jonathan Wishfort) by her Disobedience in Con∣tracting her self against your Consent or Knowledge; and by re∣fusing the offer'd Match with Sir Willfull Wiwoud, which you, like a careful Aunt, had provided for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My Nephew was non Compos; and could not make his Addresses.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: I come to make Demands,—I'll hear no Objections.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: You will grant me Time to consider.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Yes, while the Instrument is drawing, to which you must set your Hand 'till more sufficient Deeds can be perfected, which I will take care shall be done with all possible speed. In the mean while, I will go for the said Instrument, and 'till my Return you may ballance this Matter in your own Discretion. [Exit. Fain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: This Insolence is beyond all Precedent, all Parallel; must I be subject to this merciless Villain?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: 'Tis fevere indeed, Madam, that you should smart for your Daughter's Wantonness.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: 'Twas against my Consent that she marry'd this Barba∣rian, but she would have him, tho' her Year was not out.—Ah! her first Husband, my Son Languish, would not have carry'd it thus. Well, that was my Choice, this is hers; she is match'd now with a Witness—I shall be mad, dear Friend, is there no Comfort for me? Must I live to be consiscated at this rebel-rate? —Here come two more of my Egyptian Plagues too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Aunt, your Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Out Caterpillar, call not me Aunt; I know thee not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: I confess I have been a little in Disguise, as they say,— 'Sheart! and I'm sorry for't. What would you have? I hope I committed no Offence, Aunt—and if I did I am willing to make Satisfaction; and what can a Man say fairer? If I have broke any thing I'll pay for't, an it cost a Pound. And so let that content for what's past, and make no more Words. For what's to come, to pleasure you I'm willing to marry my Cousin. So pray let's all be Friends, she and I are agreed upon the Matter before a Witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: How's this, dear Neice? Have I any Comfort? Can this be true?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P:
I am content to be a Sacrifice to your Repose Madam; and to convince you that I had no Hand in the Plot, as you were misinform'd, I have laid my Commands on Mirabell to come in Person, and be Witness that I give my Hand to this Flower of Knighthood; and for the Contract that pas's'd between Mirabell
and me, I have oblig'd him to make a Resignation of it in your Ladiship's Presence;—He is without, and waits your leave for Admittance.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Well, I'll swear. I am something reviv'd at this Testimo∣ny of your Obedience; but I cannot admit that Traitor,—I fear I cannot fortifie my self to support his Appearance. He is as terrible to me as a Gorgon; if I see him I fear I shall turn to Stone, perifie incessantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: If you disoblige him he may resent your Refusal, and insist upon the Contract still. Then 'tis the last time he will be offensive to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Are you sure it will be the last time?—If I were sure of that—shall I never see him again?

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Sir Willfull, you and he are to Travel together, are you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: 'Sheart the Gentleman's a a civil Gentleman, Aunt, let him come in; why we are sworn Brothers and Fellow-Travellers. —We are to be Pylades and Orestes, he and I—He is to be my Interpreter in Foreign Parts. He has been Over-seas once already; and with proviso that I marry my Cousin, will cross 'em once again, only to bear me Company.—'Sheart, I'll call him in,—an I set on't once, he shall come in; and see who'll hin∣der him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: This is precious Fooling, if it would Pass, but I'll know the Bottom of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O dear Marwood, you are not going?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Not far, Madam; I'll return immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Look up, Man, I'll stand by you, 'sbud an she do frown, she can't kill you;—Besides—harkee she daref not rown desperately, because her Face is none of her own; 'Sheart and she shou'd her Forehead wou'd wrinkle like the Coat of a Cream-cheese, but mum for that, Fellow-Traveller.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: If a deep sense of the many Injuries I have offer'd to so good a Lady, with a sincere Remorse, and a hearty Contrition, can but obtain the least Glance of Compassion I am too happy,— Ah Madam, there was a time—But let it be forgotten— I confess I have deservedly forfeited the high Place I once held, of sighing at your Feet; nay kill me not, by turning from me in Disdain,—I come not to plead for Favour;—Nay not for Pardon, I am a Suppliant only for your Pity—I am going where I ne∣ver shall behold you more—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: How, Fellow-Traveller!—You shall go by your self then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Let me be piried first and afterwards forgotten— I ask no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: By'r Lady a very reasonable Request; and will cost you nothing, Aunt—Come, come, forgive and forget Aunt, why you must an you are Christian.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Consider Madam, in reality, you cou'd not receive much Prejudice; it was an Innocent Device; tho' I confess it had a Face of Guiltiness,—It was at most an Artifice which Love contriv'd—And Errors which Love produces have ever been ac∣counted Venial. At least think it is Punishment enough, that I have lost what in my Heart I hold most dear, that to your cruel Indignation, I have offer'd up this Beauty, and with her my Peace and Quiet; nay all my Hopes of future Comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: An he do's not move me, wou'd I might never be O' the Quorum—An it were not as good a Deed as to drink, to give her to him again,—I wou'd I might never take Ship∣ping. —Aunt, if you don't forgive quickly, I shall melt, I can tell you that. My Contract went no further than a little Mouth-Glew, and that's hardly dry;—One doleful Sigh more from my Fellow-Traveller and 'tis dissolv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Well Nephew, upon your Account—Ah, he has a false Insinuating Tongue—Well Sr, I will stifle my just Resentment at my Nephew's Request.—I will endeavour what I can to forget,—but on proviso that you resign the Contract with my Neice immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: It is in Writing and with Papers of Concern; but I have sent my Servant for it, and will deliver it to you, with all Acknowledgments for your transcendent Goodness.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Oh, he has Witchcraft in his Eyes and Tongue;— When I did not see him I could have brib'd a Villain to his As∣sassination; but his Appearance rakes the Embers which have so long lain smother'd in my Breast.—

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Your Date of Deliberation, Madam, is expir'd. Here is the Instrument, are you prepar'd to sign?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: If I were prepar'd, I am not impower'd. My Neice exerts a lawful Claim, having match'd her self by my Direction to Sir Wilfull.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: That Sham is too gross to pass on me—tho' 'tis im∣pos'd on you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Sir, I have given my Consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: And, Sir, I have resign'd my Pretensions.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
And, Sir, I assert my Right; and will maintain it in defiance
of you Sir, and of your Instrument. S'heart an you talk of an Instru∣ment Sir, I have an old Fox by my Thigh shall hack your Instrument of Ram Vellain to Shreds, Sir. It shall not be sufficient for a mitti∣mus or a Tailor's Measure; therefore withdraw your Instrument Sir, or by'r Lady I shall draw mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Hold, Nephew; hold.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Good Sir Willfull respite your Valour.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Indeed? Are you provided of your Guard, with your single Beef-eater there? But I'm prepar'd for you; and Insist upon my first Proposal. You shall submit, your own Estate to my Management, and absolutely make over my Wife's to my sole use; as pursuant to the Purport and Tenor of this other Covenant.—I suppose, Madam your Consent is not requisite in this Cafe; nor, Mr. Mirabell, your Resigna∣tion; nor, Sir, Willfull, your Right—You may draw your fox if you please Sir, and make a Bear-Garden flourish somewhere else: For here it will not avail. This, my Lady Wisbfort, must be subscrib'd, or your Darling Daughter's turn'd a-drift, like a leaky Hulk to sink or swim, as she and the Current of this lewd Town can agree.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Is there no Means, no Remedy, to stop my Ruin? Ungrate∣ful Wretch! dost thou not owe thy Being, they Subsistance to my Daugh∣ter's Fortune?

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: I'll answer you when I have the rest of it in my Possession.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: But that you wou'd not accept of a Remedy from my Hands —I own I have not deserv'd you shou'd owe any Obligation to me; or else perhaps I cou'd advise,—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O what? what? to save me and my Child from Ruin, from Want, I'll forgive all that's past; nay I'll consent to any Thing to come, to be deliver'd from this Tyranny.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Ay Madam; but that is too late, my Reward is intercepted. You have dispos'd of her, who only cou'd have made me a Compen∣sation for all my Services;—But be it as it may, I am resolv'd I'll serve you, you shall not be wrong'd in this Savage manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: How! Dear Mr. Mirabell, can you be so generous at last! But it is not possible. Harkee, I'll break my Nephew's Match, you shall have my Neice yet, and all her Fortune; if you can but save me from this imminent Danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Will you? I take you at your Word. I ask no more. I must have leave for Two Criminals to appear.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Ay, ay, any body, any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Foible is one, and a Penitent.
SP.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Fainall, Foible, and Mincing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: O my Shame! thes corrupt things are {Mira and Lady go to Mrs. Fain. and Foib. bought and brought hither to expose me.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: If it must all come out, why let 'em know it, 'tis but the Way of the World. That shall not urge me to relinquish or abate one Tittle of my Terms, no, I will insist the more.

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: Yes indeed Madam; I'll take my Bible-oath of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Minc.
SP.P: And so will I Mem.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O Marwood, Marwood, art thou false? my Friend deceive me? Hast thou been a wicked Accomplice with that profligate Man?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
