SP.P: Have you so much Ingratitude and Injustice, to give Credit against you Friend, to the Aspersions of Two such mercenary Truls?

SP.SPEAKER: Minc.
SP.P: Mercenary, Mem? I scorn your Words. Tis true we found you and Mr. Fainall in the blue Garret; by the same Token, you swore us to Secresie upon Messalinas's Poems. Mercenary? No, if we wou'd have been Mercenary, we shou'd have held our Tongues; You wou'd have brib'd us sufficiently.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Go, you are an Insignificant thing.—Well, what are you the better for this! Is this Mr. Mirabell's Expedient? I'll be put off no longer—You Thing that was a Wife, shallsmart for this. I will not leave thee wherewithall to hide thy Shame: Your Body shall be Naked as your Reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: I despise you, and desie your Malice—You have as∣pers'd me wrongfully—I have prov'd your Falshhood—Go you and your treacherous—I will not name it, but starve to∣gether —Perish.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Not while you are wroth a Groat, indeed my Dear. Madam, I'll be fool'd no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Ah Mr. Mirabell, this is small Comfort, the Detection of this Affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: O in good time—Your leave for the other Offender and Penitent to appear, Madam.
SP.STAGE: Enter Waitwell with a Box of Writings.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O Sir Rowland—Well, Rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: What your Ladiship pleases.—I have brought the Black-Box at last, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Give it me. Madam, you remember your Promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I, dear Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Where are the Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Wait.
SP.P: At hand Sir, rubbing their Eyes,—Just risen from Sleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: S'death what's this to me? I'll not wait your private Concerns.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: How now? What's the matter? who's Hand's out?

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Hey day! what are you all got together, like Players at the End of the last Act?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: You may remember, Gentlemen, I once requested your hands as Witnesses to a certain Parchment.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: Ay I do, my Hand I remember—Petlant set his Mark.

SP.SPEAKER: Mir.
SP.P: You wrong him, his Nameis fairly written, as shall appear— You do not remember, Gentlemen, any thing of what that Parch∣ment contain'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: No. Pet. Not I. I writ, I read nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Very well, now you shall know—Madam, your promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Ay, ay, Sir, upon my Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Mr. Fainall, it is now Time that you shou'd know, that your Lady, while she was at her own Disposal, and before you had by your Insinuations wheadl'd her out of a pretended Settlement of the great∣est Part of her Fortune—

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Sir! pretended!

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Yes, Sir. I say that this Lady while a Window, having it seems receiv'd some Cautions respecting your Inconstancy and Tyranny of Temper, which from her own partial Opinion and Fondness of you she cou'd never have suspected—she did, I say, by the wholesome Advice of Friends and of Sages learn'd in the Laws of this Land, de∣liver this same as her Act and Deed to me in Trust, and to the Uses within mention'd. You may read if you please—[Holding out the Parchment.] tho perhaps what is inscrib'd on the Back may serve your Occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Very likely, Sir. What's here? Damnation?

DIV3.P: [Reads.] A Deed of Conveyance of the whole Estate real of Arabel∣la Languish, Widow, in Trust to Edward Mirabell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Even so, Sir; 'tis the Way of the World, Sir; of the Wi∣dows of the World. I suppose this Deed may bear an elder Date than what you have obtain'd from your Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Persidious Fiend! then thus I'll be reveng'd.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Hold, Sir, now you may make your Bear-Garden Flou∣rish somewhere else, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fain.
SP.P: Mirabell, you shall hear of this, Sir, be sure you shall. —Let me pass, Oaf.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Madam, you seem to stifle your Resentment: You had better give it Vent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Mar.
SP.P: Yes, it shall have Vent—and to your Consusion, or I'll perish in the Attempt.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: O Daughter, Daughter, 'tis plain thou hast inherited thy Mother's Prudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Fain.
SP.P: Thank Mr. Mirabell, a cautious Friend, to whose Ad∣vice all is owing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
Well Mr. Mirabell, you have kept your Promise—and I must
perform mine-First I pardon for your sake Sir Rowland there and Foible,—The next thing is to break the Matter to my Nephew and how to do that—

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: For that, Madam, give your self no Trouble,—let me have your Consent—Sir Willfull is my Friend; he has had Compassi∣on upon Lovers, and generously engag'd a Volunteer in this Action, for our Service, and now designs to prosecute his Travels.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: 'Sheart, Aunt, I have no mind to marry. My Cousin's a sine Lady, and the Gentleman loves her and she loves him, and they deserve one another; my Resolution is to see Foreign Parts—I have set on't—and when I'm set on't, I must do't. And if these two Gentle∣men wou'd travel too, I think they may be spar'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pet.
SP.P: For my part, I say little—I think things are best off or on.

SP.SPEAKER: Wit.
SP.P: I gad I understand nothing of the matter,—I'm in a Maze yet, like a Dog in a Dancing School.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Well Sir, take her, and with her all the Joy I can give you.

SP.SPEAKER: Milla.
SP.P: Why does not the Man take me? Wou'd you have me give my self to you over again?

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Ay, and over and over again; [Kisses her Hand.] I would have you as often as possibly I can. Well, Heav'n grant I Love you not too well, that's all my Fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: 'Sheart you'll have him time enough to toy after you're marry'd; or if you will toy now, let us have a Dance in the mean time, that we who are not Lovers may have some other Employment, besides looking on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: With all my heart. dear Sir Willfull; what shall we do for Musick?

SP.SPEAKER: Foib.
SP.P: O Sir, some that were provided for Sir Rowland's Entertain∣ment are yet within Call.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: As I am a Person I can hold out no longer;—I have wasted my Spirits so to Day already, that I am ready to sink under the Fa∣tigue; and I cannot but have some Fears upon me yet, that my Son Fainall will pursue some desperate Course.

SP.SPEAKER: Mira.
SP.P: Madam, disquiet not your self on that account; to my know∣ledge his Circumstances are such, he must of Force comply. For my part I will contribute all that in me lyes to a reunion: In the mean time, Madam, [To Mrs. Fain.] let me before these Witnesses restore to you this Deed of Trust; it may be a Means, well manag'd, to make you live easily together.
SP.L: From hence let those be warn'd, who mean to wed;
Left mutual Falshood stain the Bridal-Bed:
For each Deceiver to his Cost may find,
That Marriage Frauds too oft are paid in kind.
